Speaker: Mr MILES
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Braddon-Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister) (9.31 a.m.)-I move: That the bill be now read a second time. The bill will amend the taxation laws in a number of respects. It delivers on the government's election commitments to provide a tax rebate for low income aged persons and allowing equity investments in SMEs to be taxed under the CGT provisions. In addition the bill implements 1996-97 budget announcements relating to the medical expenses rebate, sale of mining rights, cooperatives, infrastructure borrowings and research and development. Tax rebate for low income aged persons The bill implements the election commitment to provide a tax rebate to persons of age pension age who do not receive the age pension. To be eligible, a taxpayer will have to meet the same residency criteria as age pensioners and have a taxable income below the pensioner rebate cut-out thresholds. This measure builds on other assistance to older persons which the government has provided since the election including the reduction of the provisional tax uplift factor from eight per cent to six per cent for the 1996-97 financial year. As a transitional measure, the new rebate for the 1996-97 income year will be at a level equivalent to half the pensioner rebate for 1996-97. For subsequent years, the new rebate will be at the same level as the pensioner rebate. These changes will result in an estimated reduction in revenue of $10 million in 1996-97, $48 million in 1997-98 and $65 million in 1998-99 and the following year. Equity investments in small-medium enterprises The bill also implements the government's election commitment relating to equity investments in small-medium enterprises which was also announced in the budget. The provisions amend the income tax law to provide an incentive for lending institutions to make long-term investments in the small business sector. The changes will encourage banks to become equity partners in SMEs and help alleviate the debt-financing problems suffered by many of these businesses. The amendments change the tax treatment of certain equity investments from being on revenue account to being treated under the capital gains tax provisions. They will apply to investments made after 1 July 1996. Medical expenses rebate The government announced in the budget that the threshold for the medical expenses rebate would be raised from $1,000 to $1,500. The increase in the threshold applies from budget night, so that for the 1996-97 income year the threshold will be $1,430. Medical expenses in excess of the threshold qualify for a rebate at the rate of 20c in the dollar on the excess. As only medical expenses net of reimbursements from health funds qualify for the rebate, the increase in the threshold is consistent with other incentives announced in the budget for people to take out private health insurance. The increase in the threshold is expected to raise additional revenue of $26 million in 1997 -98, $23 million in 1998-99 and $24 million in 1999-2000. Sale of mining rights Another budget measure to be implemented by this bill concerns the sale of mining rights. The bill will withdraw the exemption from tax on income from the sale, transfer or assignment of mining rights for gold or other prescribed metals or minerals. Income from the sale of mining rights under contracts entered into after 31 December 1996 will no longer be exempt. The estimated revenue saving is $2 million in 1997-98, $20 million in 1998-99, and $40 million per year thereafter. Cooperative companies The bill implements the repeal of paragraph 120(l)(c) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 announced in the budget. The measures will prevent the effective 200 per cent tax deduction which was previously available for the cost of certain assets and which provided cooperatives and government lending institutions with commercial and taxation advantages over other companies. These advantages are not justifiable and are inconsistent with competitive neutrality principles. This measure will apply to government loans entered into after 7.30 p.m. eastern standard time on 20 August 1996 and to existing loans only where their terms are altered after this time subject to transitional arrangements. The first transitional arrangement ensures that certain loans to eligible cooperatives that were entered into after 7.30 p.m. on 20 August 1996, but on or before 31 December 1996, will remain eligible for the paragraph 120(l)(c) tax deduction provided the company has in the three years leading up to 20 August 1996 had a loan to which paragraph 120(l)(c) applies. This transitional provision applies if the loan was entered into for the sole purpose of acquiring a specified asset pursuant to: an authorisation given by the directors of the cooperative before 7.30 p.m. on 20 August 1996 (and recorded in the minutes of the co-operative) to acquire the asset, provided the authorisation to acquire the asset is in accordance with an approved business plan and the asset is contracted by 31 December 1996; or a contract that was entered into before 7.30 p.m. on 20 August 1996. The specified asset must be plant or articles for the purposes of section 54 of the act (other than a passenger motor vehicle) or an eligible building for the purposes of section 124ZF of the act. It must be installed ready for use by 30 June 1998. A further transitional provision applies where a cooperative has entered into a contract-which may include a verbal contractbefore 7.30 p.m. on 20 August 1996 to acquire an asset and has an agreement for the provision of finance before that time. In such a case, any drawdowns of funds under that agreement after that time for the sole purpose of acquiring the asset will be eligible for the tax deduction. The reference in these transitional provisions to an asset would include a group of assets within a particular project. The measure is expected to save the revenue $2 million in 1997-98, $4 million in 1998-99 and $6 million in 1999-2000. Infrastructure borrowings--amendments of the Development Allowance Authority Act 1992 The objective of the amendments to the Development Allowance Authority Act 1992 is to prevent certain types of schemes undermining the integrity of the infrastructure borrowings program by breaking the symmetry in the special tax treatments of the payer and receiver of interest. Such schemes enable indirect infrastructure borrowings to be made functionally independent of the financing of an infrastructure project thereby increasing the value of tax benefits to those involved and the cost to revenue without a commensurate increase in the funding for private sector projects. The amendments will give effect to the budget announcement designed to prevent those sorts of schemes from undermining the integrity of the infrastructure borrowings program. As was stated in statement 4 in Budget Paper No.1: 'If allowed to proceed, such schemes would substantially increase the value of tax benefits to those involved, and the cost to revenue, without a commensurate for increase in the funding for private sector infrastructure projects.' The amending legislation will require: new indirect infrastructure borrowings or refinancing infrastructure borrowings that succeed them to be made only by Australian resident taxpayers; and any transfer of rights by a direct infrastructure borrowing lender or repayment of a direct infrastructure borrowing, to be accompanied by repayment or parallel transfer of any associated indirect infrastructure borrowing or refinancing infrastructure borrowing that has succeeded the indirect infrastructure borrowing. The amendments, which will have effect from 30 October 1995, will not prevent infrastructure borrowings from operating in the way intended by the government to encourage the genuine private sector development of publicly accessible infrastructure. The amendments have the potential to prevent a future loss to the revenue. The amount of potential revenue loss is not quantifiable. Research and development activities The bill will also amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the Industry, Research and Development Act 1986 to give effect to policy changes announced by the government on 23 July and 20 August 1996. The concessional deduction rate for R&D expenditure is being reduced from 150 per cent to 125 per cent and new syndicates are prevented from claiming R&D deductions. The R&D deduction rules for interest, core technology, pilot plant and feedstock are also being modified. The definition of R&D activities is being clarified. The tax concession for eligible R&D nevertheless remains generous. It allows immediate deduction or rapid write-off of expenditures which may otherwise be capital or deductible over longer periods. Even the reduced premium rate of deduction provides a considerable degree of concessionality. The bill amends the Industry, Research and Development Act 1986 to remove the ability of companies to register jointly for the R&D tax concession or, as it is more commonly known, to register a syndicate. Joint registration has facilitated arrangements that provide considerably greater tax benefits than the benefits provided to other registrants under the R&D tax concession. This level of tax benefit was clearly unintended. The government considers that quality R&D can be promoted effectively through other mechanisms, including the new START program, at lower cost to the Australian taxpayer. Other minor amendments to the Industry, Research and Development Act 1986 include the streamlining of grant provisions to make them more clear, and the introduction of a mechanism by which the minister can provide formal advice to the Industry Research and Development Board and its committees in an open and transparent manner. These changes will result in a gain to revenue of $59 million in 1996-97, $718 million in 1997-98, $630 million in 1998-99, and $840 million in 19992000. Tax exempt entities that become taxable The bill proposes to amend the income tax law to deal with transition issues that arise when previously tax exempt entities become taxable. The measures were announced by the previous government on 3 July 1995 and apply to entities becoming taxable on or after that date. The amendments will generally allocate income, gains, losses and deductions of an entity between its exempt and taxable periods. The amendments minimise compliance costs for entities that are becoming taxable. Deductions for post transition costs in respect of pre-transition leave, eligible termination payments, bad debts and superannuation are to be determined by reference to liabilities accumulated at the date of transition rather than by reference to the particular cost. The amendments are expected to be revenue neutral. Rebatable annuities The bill closes a loophole in the law that allowed the conversion of non-rebatable annuities to rebatable annuities and pensions. Amendments to the tax law in 1994 to allow the unused undeducted purchase price of a commuted superannuation pension or rollover annuity to be further rolled over had the unintended consequence of allowing amounts received on commutation or termination of annuities purchased with money outside the superannuation system to be treated as eligible termination payments-ETPs. These ETPs could then be rolled over into the superannuation system to purchase rebatable annuities and pensions. This rebate is intended to apply only to superannuation pensions and rollover annuities. Annuities that have not been purchased with amounts accumulated within the superannuation system should not be eligible for concessional taxation treatment that has been earmarked for genuine superannuation amounts. The bill will ensure that, subject to excepPeople tions designed to maintain the current treatment of some annuities purchased on or before 9 December 1987, only annuities purchased wholly from ETP moneys are treated as ETPs on commutation or termination and can be rolled over to purchase rebatable annuities and pensions. The measure will apply to annuities commuted or terminated on or after 15 June 1996. It is not expected to raise any additional revenue. However, failure to act to close the loophole would have posed a potentially significant threat to the revenue. Full details of the measures in the bill are contained in the explanatory memorandum circulated to honourable members. I commend the bill to the House. Debate (on motion by Mr O'Connor) adjourned. Speaker: Dr LAWRENCE
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION LEGISLATION
text: Fremantle) (9.48 a.m.)I rise to continue remarks that I began last night in relation to the Higher Education Legislation Amendment Bill. The bill increases HECS payments, it introduces differential HECS, it lowers the HECS repayment threshold and makes cuts to university funding. I think it is important, as I indicated night, that in examining these changes we look at the effects not only on individuals but on the community as a whole, something the government appears not to have done. It appears to see education, as I indicated last night, principally as conferring individual financial benefit, and therefore more appropriclassroom. ately funded by the individual, almost regardless of their ability to pay. I want to look briefly this morning, because I have only a few minutes, at the consequences that will be adverse both to individuals and to the nation as a whole. As I indicated, talent will be diverted from low paying occupations to high paying occupations. will obviously see that in the future they will not be able, for instance, in areas of science and research, to earn the sort of money that will enable them to clear the HECS debts, particularly now that science and engineering have been placed in the middle range-and expensive range at that-of the differential HECS. People will clearly be discouraged, too, from entering areas of work where a degree of public service and self-sacrifice is required but where the pay is poor, because the impact of the HECS repayments will hit hard over a longer period-for instance, on a lawyer who chooses to go into community or Aboriginal legal service as opposed to a private law firm. Law, of course, will be in the most expensive stream. But there are many lawyers, including members of my own family, who practise in low paid fields like community law, Aboriginal legal services and the like. In the future they will find there is a considerable personal financial handicap in doing that. Many will be discouraged from seeking entry at all to the universities because of anxiety about the substantially enlarged HECS debt, whatever strand they are in. I have a recent example, if members opposite think this is hypothetical, from a high school in my electorate, Hamilton Senior High School, which covers an area where there are a large number of people from non-English speaking backgrounds and considerable financial disadvantage. The school has worked very hard to encourage students to contemplate last university as an option following school leaving. In this case, a very bright young woman, judged by the teacher to be the brightest in the class, at the moment when the others were asked to go to put their preferences for university enrolment, stayed put in her seat in the When asked by the teacher why she was not going to enrol, she said, 'My family and I discussed it and we decided we can't afford that kind of debt hanging over our heads. We have never done it for any other reason and they won't allow me to do it now. I don't want to do it, either.' Fortunately, she was talked into enrolling, but whether when it comes to the crunch she actually goes is another matter. This is especially a problem for women who are already in the work force and for the so-called battlers that this government purports to care about who have no history of family indebtedness, let alone for education, and it is something that they will not contemplate now. There will be a lower threshold for repayment and that will force a lot of people, frankly, into poverty. They will begin paying their HECS debts below the poverty line. When you look at the child-care fee increases that we will discuss later today, that will be exacerbated. Enrolments in science and technology are already falling. The effects on the nation's skill base will be incalculable. The quality of education generally will undoubtedly suffer because of the cuts to operating grants to the universities. Choices are already being forced on universities that they do not like, to have to cut faculties and departments from their existing operation. So it reduces students' choice as well. Merit based places will be squeezed by the allowance of 25 per cent of places for those who can afford to pay. This is discriminatory and simply serves the wealthy. It will put us in the position of having one of the lowest levels of government, as opposed to individual, funding per student in the OECD. Some students will be paying more than 50 per cent of their course costs. This is higher than in the United States, where families start saving for higher education as soon as their children are born. We very definitely oppose this lation.

Speaker: Mr ALLAN MORRIS
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION LEGISLATION
text: I approach the debate on the Higher Education Legislation Amendment Bill with some sadness. Right now the community of Newcastle are being bashed, buffeted and traduced by this government in one way or another, either by neglect or by deliberate policy. In the past I have not had as many people come to me after a budget with their individual problems, expressing how it is affecting them personally. In the months ahead, those opposite are going to find that some of the judgments they made in approaching government and in their period in government have laid a very bad basis. They will live to regret very much many of their actions. Throughout this budget session, we have been dealing with legislation about health, education and social security, which in theory is about those areas of activity, but which in practice is about something else. In practice it is about philosophy of government and the role of government in our society. It is about putting into practice an ideology that says that government effectively should not exist, that there is very little role for a federal parliament other than to raise taxes and for foreign affairs and defence. All the other functions should be transferred either to the states or to business. Speaker after speaker from the government side in this debate has referred to education as a business. Everything eventually seems to come down to a business-health is a business; education is a business. Everything seems to be put through a filter of business parameters. For me, education is not a business at all. It is a fundamentally important part of our society which the government is responsible for. The abdication of responsibility in transferring functions to the state or withdrawing from activities is an abdication of the greatest significance to this country. What we are seeing reflected in this legislation and this approach in many ways is poll driven and harks back 30 or 40 years to when education at universities was for a very small number-for the so-called elite. I well relegismember the differentiation between the eggheads-the academics, the ivory towerists, the very small number who went to university-who were never representative of mainstream Australia, and the so-called battlers. That is 40 years out of date. Nowadays university education is a natural, normal part of our society. It is not something special, different and elite. It is an extension of the education of our very talented population. Back in the sixties we were very lucky to be at universities if we could afford it. Many of us worked part-time and paid our fees in advance. We understood that the general community did not necessarily support that. Those kinds of attitudes in the sixties meant that by the eighties we were seeing school participation rates of 35 per cent. In the early eighties about one-third of our young people were staying on to year 12 to matriculation standard. That was an appalling figure. Why? Because the government of the day saw education as a function for the elite. It was not a function for normal Australians; it was a function for special people and, therefore, only had special privileges. The member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) in recent times said that it wasn't surprising that people who were wealthy had intelligent children. That amazingly elitist and circular argument was perhaps an unconscious expression of many of those opposite. They are still trying to tum us back to the days when education at university was for a small number of special people. Their speciality was not to do with their intellect or their ability. It was to do with where they came from. When I was a student, the vast number of students at universities were being paid for by their parents. If your parents could not afford to send you to university, you did not go-unless you got a scholarship, and there were not many of those. What we are seeing now is a shifting back. Many Australians will agree with this. Many Australians resent the fact that somehow their taxes are being used for personal gain by somebody else. That is that old attitude-the 'them and us'-to create resentment against this so-called elite. It is pretty obvious that most of those opposite do not visit universities very often and do not talk to students very much. If they did, they would find that students are not elite. They are not some group of special people who are going to benefit massively from education. The idea that schoolteachers are some group of elite is a nonsense. The salaries being paid to graduates nowadays are relatively minor. People are now forced to make a choicewhether to spend three or four years at university and forgo income, promotion and establishment in an organisation. That is now a major decision. In the past people had to weigh up the fact that they would have to forgo four years of income, which would mean that they would be behind before they even started. Now they have a debt on top of that. It has become quite clear that many people who do not see high incomes in their area of activity-whether it be in some of the community health fields or community service fields or even in teaching-have to decide whether it is worth their while to forgo those years of income and accrue a debt. The sums are very likely now to be against going to university. What happens then? As a society we de-skill. We tum away from education. If people think this might be an exaggeration, just look at the figures. Press reports indicate that the number of people seeking enrolment at Newcastle University this year will be down 10 per cent. Why? Why would a government want to do this? Why would a government want to deskill its community? Where is the benefit? What is being reported as a thesis? To educate them gives them a personal gain and therefore they should pay for it. As I have pointed out, for many people there will be no personal gain, or a very minor one, or the effects will be negative. Many people will go to university and not be successful for one reason or another-ill health or other circumstances-and they will end up with a debt and no income. For a family without a background of wealth, without a background of academic achievement, the attitude will be: don't take the risk; don't bother. Some have argued that because the previous government brought in the HECS, somehow we and the present government are like peas in a pod, that we are as one. It is important to clarify that position. Years ago, when we came into government, we started to understand that the skilling of our community was so limited that we needed to accelerate education at a much greater rate than other areas of activity. It became very clear that many taxpayers would resent the need to spend at a much higher rate on higher education, so we sought to balance the individual benefit against the community benefit and government responsibility through the introduction of the HECS. At the moment there is well over $3 billion in accumulated debt to government through the HECS from people at university or who have graduated from university. That debt is being paid back when people reach an income of, at the moment, $28,000, which is a reasonable income. That contribution allows the education sector to grow at a much faster rate than other areas of government spending. The failure of those opposite to understand that was exemplified in the comments made by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) a few months back when she cast aspersions on the fact that higher education had grown 60 per cent. She asked why it should grow faster than roads and other areas of spending. That indicated her absolute ignorance. Education had grown at a faster rate because we had asked those involved to contribute. They had not wanted to-make no mistake. It was not the choice of students in those days to do that. But education, under our government, grew at a much faster rate because we had asked those involved to contribute via HECS. We did not regard it as a business or as some way of extracting money from those who would earn more, but as a contribution which, through a sense of social justice, would allow education to grow at a faster rate than roads and other areas of government spending. Those opposite saw this, to use the words of Senator Vanstone at that time, as some sort of pay-off by the Labor government to people who were Labor inclined. What a travesty, what an absolute disgrace for the now minister to have expressed those kinds of thoughts. We understood that if we were to compete in the world of the present and of the future we would need a much more highly skilled population. When we look at the way in which university graduates are utilised in our society-be it in accounting, hospitality or higher sciences-there is no doubt that the achievements of a much higher population of graduates are being felt. Comments have been made in recent times about the greater numbers of foreign language speakers-Japanese, Indonesian-particularly at university level. Their .impact has been enormous and is fundamentally important to building a base for our business people and traders. Then there is the fact that higher education is probably our single biggest foreign exchange earner, worth $2 billion a year. This country treats education as a commodity for sale but, because we have a very high standard, those who see it simply as a business somehow distort the situation. This government has achieved a pretty wonderful trifecta in recent times. Yesterday's balance of payments statement will not be the last of the bad economic news. The government has taken a healthy economy--one of the best economies in the world in terms of debt or any other factor you want to nameand talked it into a recession. I see that the member for Warringah (Mr Abbott) thinks this is very funny. But yesterday's balance of payments was way over expectations. Growth in this country has dropped from 2.1 per cent in the March quarter to 0.1 per cent in the June quarter. Unemployment is increasing week by week. The long-term unemployed are increasing at 5,000 a month. This is very funny! The situation will not get any better; it will get worse. You know it and we know it. The jobs committee is a charade, created by the very people who are wiping out jobs. With this government we are seeing ideology running rampant, and the latest victims are students. Today's Sydney Morning Herald points out that one in five Australian students will suffer. Why? Because those opposite have never understood the problem and do not understand now. I want to mention the trifecta of problems that the University of Newcastle is suffering. Firstly, there is a 10 per cent reduction in those seeking to enrol there. From discussions in recent days with people from that university who work in the overseas market-passing the on what is happening in places like Singapore for the possible intake of students next yearthe message is a disastrous one. Without doubt, what is happening in Australia right now will affect Newcastle university's intake of students from Asia next year. Our income from overseas students might well go down and that will cost us jobs. Why? Because those opposite do not understand what they are doing. But they let these issues run on because they might be popular at the time. The fact is that cuts in university funding, changes to the higher education contribution scheme fees, massive changes to Austudy and, of course, the perception abroad that Asians are not welcome here will cost my community. They will cost us jobs and they will cost us opportunities. They will also cost us investment. It was said by a previous speaker that the government had introduced the proposal to raise the BEeS charges so as to make sure that people who were benefiting were contributing. The fact is that the changes proposed will mean that the cost of a law degree will go up. Yet the actual cost of teaching that law degree is much lower than a medicine or veterinary science degree, which of course are the other two degrees on the same scale. These fees are not about cost recovery. They are about a form of charging on a projected benefit. That may be well and good, but that is not about cost recovery. It is about taxation. In other words, the schemes are working in two ways. Firstly, they are a tax driven scheme. Secondly, they are a tax designed scheme in terms of the charges that are being imputed. It is about time the government came clean about that. The other thing that is going to affect fees is the lower threshold. The fact is that the government's proposal to reduce the threshold to just over $20,000 means that many of the part-time students in my electorate who are undertaking university courses-in many cases, they are relatively young people who are raising families, paying off mortgages and going to university as an attempt to broaden and strengthen their capacity for a future career and job satisfaction-will be paying off these charges as they go. Not when they get a high enough income to afford them, but when they reach $20,000. Many people in part-time work or on lower incomes who are trying to improve their circumstances by going to university will be paying these charges week by week, month by month. That was not what the scheme was about-ever. The fact that it has been pushed that way is indicative of the lack of understanding shown by this government. The lower threshold alone will be enough to discourage many people from improving themselves and learning new skills. What is the benefit of that? One has to look at the legislation and ask, 'What is its objective?' Like most of the legislation we are dealing with in this session, it is not about improving education at all. It is about finding ways to rip money off people who, in most cases, cannot afford it. We had the spectacle of the mlTIlster in Asia last week telling Asian leaders and those interested in Australian education that what was going on here would actually be of benefit. She said that Malaysian students and Asian students would find the universities of Australia better than before. What a lie. What a deceit. What a disgraceful thing to say. That is not the case, and she knows it and we all know it. What is more, the Asians know it. I do not know who she thought she was kidding, but the fact is she did not kid anybody. All of those things are telling us that the government want to tum back the clock. They want the universities to go back to being the location for the elite-because, after all, as the member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly) said, the only ones who are bright are those who are rich. So let them go to university. The government is saying, 'Let us tum the universities back to those days. Let us make sure the community out there understand that we are not really supportive of Asians being educated here.' As I said, my university is earning millions of dollars a year and employing people out of the fees being charged to people from Asia. But we have just told those people, 'Don't come. We don't like you.' What is more, the education centres are going to go down because the government is disinvesting. It is withdrawing funding from universities. That is a disgrace. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION LEGISLATION
text: Warringah-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs) (10.12 a.m.)-in reply-In his contribution to the debate, the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) lamented the fact, as he saw it, that there were no intelligent conservatives left. Let me put it to the member for Melbourne and to other members opposite that this is highly intelligent, conservative policy making because this bill builds on the strengths of the existing system. It is the job of intelligent conservatives to reject change for change's sake while making necessary change palatable by stressing the enduring strengths and continuities of our system. The member for Sydney and the shadow minister for education and youth affairs (Mr Peter Baldwin) finds it easy to criticise but hard to be convincing, because what he is criticising is, in essence, a development and refinement of policies put in place, however reluctantly, by the previous government. Obviously, the fact that we are building on the former government's work shows that it was not all bad. The member for Melbourne and many members opposite have praised the work of Gough Whitlam for abolishing university fees in 1973. It is fair enough for them to do so. But, in praising the work of former Prime Minister Whitlam, they are criticising the work of the former minister for education, Mr Dawkins, and his prime ministerial bosses, Mr Hawke and Mr Keating. It was the Labor Party under Gough Whitlam which ended fees, but it was also the Labor Party under Mr Dawkins, Mr Hawke and Mr Keating which restored fees. If fees are a problem, we must blame the Labor Party, because it was the Labor Party which introduced fees in the guise of the higher education contribution scheme. Yet they had good reasons for doing so. The former Minister for Finance, Senator Peter Walsh, said: In 1985 we knew that 10 years of "free" tertiary education had not changed students' socio-economic background. Taxpayers were no longer subsidising education for the socio-economic elite; they were paying the entire bill. That is what former Senator Walsh thought. That is what the former government thought. That is the way the former government acted. If there is any problem with HECS, it should be sheeted home to the former government. The HECS system is a good system. It is a good system because it combines in a rather ingenious way elements of user pays with social equity. It has been very disappointing to find member after member opposite reopening the class war-a class war which should be dead and buried in this country. Certainly, it comes ill from members opposite to try to reopen the class war over a HECS system which their government introduced. The beauty of HECS is that no-one has to pay for their university education until they are in a position to do so. Let me very briefly run through the changes to the HECS system that the government is introducing in this legislation. Existing students pay the same HECs. Yes, we are lowering the threshold at which that same monetary amount is to be repaid, but it is worth remembering that the level at which former students will be required to pay their HECs is the same level at which the previous government thought people should be prepared to pay a substantial increase in their rate of tax. What we are doing is entirely consistent with the thinking of the previous government. Let us put the HECS repayments into context. A graduate who earns $21,000 a year will be paying HECs at the rate of $12 a week. That is the price of a movie ticket, a couple of packets of cigarettes or one round of drinks at the pub and that is the price of a university education. It is a very fair price indeed. A former student who earns $40,000 a year will be repaying HECs at the rate of $40 a week. That is less than the price of a restaurant meal for a couple. It is a very fair price for people to be paying for their university education. Even people studying medicine or law and paying HECs at the highest rate will find that their university education costs less than the price of a Holden car. In other words, the amount of money they are paying for an education which will be a productive asset for the rest of their lives, an education that will stand them in good stead for the rest of their lives, is less than the price of new Holden Commodore. Quite frankly, what we need to do in this country is to value our cars less and our university degrees more. Let me quote Neville Wran, who chaired a report which recommended not only the introduction of the HECS system but the introduction of differential HECS for people doing different courses. The Wran report said that 'considerable private benefits accrue to those who have the opportunity to participate'. The Wran report went on: Graduates typically get better jobs, experience little unemployment and earn relatively high incomes over their lifetimes, compared with nongraduates. When graduates commence employment, generally when they are in their mid twenties, their salaries compare favourably with the average earnings for all employees in the Australian workforce ... Neville Wran, the former National President of the ALP and the former Labor Premier of New South Wales, recommended in 1988that is almost 10 years ago-$3,000 a year for full-time students in medicine, dentistry, agriculture, forestry and veterinary science; $2,500 for a year for full-time students in engineering, surveying, science, applied science and health sciences except nursing; and $1,500 a year for full-time students in all other courses. So what the government is doing is taking up and implementing the recommendations of Neville Wran. There has been a lot of talk from members opposite about the alleged horrors of introducing full fee paying courses for some domestic undergraduates. Again we are building on the work of our predecessors. We are building on the work of the former Labor government, which introduced full fee paying courses for overseas students and which permitted full fee paying courses for local students doing postgraduate work. So we are building on the work of the ALP-nothing more and nothing less. We are taking the system it left us and we are further developing and refining the logic of that system. For members opposite to wax outraged about the existence of full fee courses for postgraduate students comes pretty ill. What members opposite are really doing is saying that postgraduate students, who in the case of a Melbourne university MBA earn on average $95,000 a year on completion of their course, should not be paying anything. So, according to members opposite, the taxpayers of Australia, rich and poor alike, should be subsidising people who are about to earn $95,000 a year. By allowing full fee paying courses for Australian students we are remedying a fundamental unfairness in the previous government's arrangements. The previous government allowed overseas students to buy very a place at Australian universities, but it would not allow Australians to do what foreigners could do. It was an unfair system. It should be changed and we are changing it. Let me remind the House exactly what we are doing. Sure, some Australian undergraduates will pay full fees, but this can only happen once all the HECS places in anyone course are filled. So this will be in addition to the HECS places, not in substitution of the HECS places. No university can offer fee paying undergraduate places before all its HECS places in that course have been filled. Fee paying places cannot exceed 25 per cent of the total places in any undergraduate course. This is clear government policy and we are absolutely, completely and utterly committed to it. Members opposite have cried crocodile tears over the alleged cuts to the higher education budget. Let us put it in perspective. Next year Australian universities will be receiving $56 million more from the taxpayers than they have received this year. Next year, the year after, the year after that and on into the future, Australian universities will be receiving in the order of $5 billion a year from the Australian taxpayers. That is the reality. The Australian government is completely committed to an excellent system of higher education. We are putting our money where our principles are to the tune of $5 billion or more every year. Let us consider what the academics say. As we know, the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee quite courageously has recommended to the Senate that the government's higher education budget package be passed. Professor Brown of the University of Sydney said: It is entirely reasonable that there should be a component of user contribution and that universities should be required to demonstrate the efficiency of their operations. I quote from a newspaper article what Professor Gilbert of the University of Melbourne has said: The Federal Government could cut university funding by 3 per cent this yearwe are not doing that, I hasten to addwithout compromising election promises, the ViceChancellor of the University of Melbourne, Professor Alan Gilbert, said yesterday. He later told The Australian that "quite a of vice-chancellors don't say publicly what they privately" on issues including fees and differential HECS charges. He said some vice-chancellors were "isolating themselves from the debate" because of the "Whitlamesque legacy" of slogans such as "education should be free for all". "So if they could announce 3 per cent cuts and introduce a number of revenue-side measures ... packaging them together would allow them to use higher education to make major inroads on deficit management without breaking their election promises". Professor Gilbert went on to say on another occasion: Simple opposition to the Budget's revenue-side measures will leave Australian universities with few alternatives to the melancholy tyranny of cuts and loss of quality. So in opposing the very sensible measures included in this budget, members opposite are exposing the universities 'to the melancholy tyranny of cuts and loss of quality'. It is important to remember something of the Labor Party's record. In 13 years of Labor government, funding for students declined by six per cent. Between 1989 and 1992, undergraduate entrant numbers dropped from lO2,000 to 93,000. Over the decade of the 1980s, the staff-student ratio in Australian universities declined from 12 to one to 16 to one. It behoves members opposite to stop running around scaring people and to accept that what we are trying to do is to take the system that we have inherited from Labor and make it work better. Let me take up a few specific points that were made by members opposite. The member for Sydney, the shadow minister said that we should be making these changes after an inquiry, not before an inquiry. It would be a fair point if what we are doing is revolutionising the system; we are not. These are evolutionary changes. You do not need an inquiry to go further down the road that the Labor Party pioneered. Members opposite have been saying that we are facing a catastrophe in terms of enrolments for science and engineering courses. Yes, early figures do suggest that applications number for some courses in some states are down. say But the fact is applications have not closed. It is far too early to tell whether the number and quality of science and engineering students coming out of school will change. Let us suppose that, yes, in the wash-up applications do go down a little bit; let us suppose that happens. Would that be terrible disaster? If it is a terrible disaster, let us accept that we have faced that disaster before. According to the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, applications over the last two years have declined by six per cent. The supplementation issue has excited some members opposite. Let me point out that the government has not ruled out supplementation for academic pay increases. But the universities should know this: it is up to them to negotiate the best deal they can with their staff, without calling upon the taxpayer to act as a security blanket before the negotiations have been completed. The idea that university academics should be running a kind of 'one in, all in' industrial campaign as if they were unskilled militant workers is, quite frankly, an insult to their professionalism and their individuality. Let me quote Frank Hambly, the executive director of the Australian ViceChancellors Committee, who says of our industrial relations reforms: The reforms will help universities cope much better Let me also quote Professor Cliff Blake, the President of the Australian Higher Education Industrial Association, who says of university industrial practices: We still have a lot of work practices which one would have to question. These are precisely the things that the universities will be able to tackle under the industrial system introduced by my friend and colleague the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith). Let me say in conclusion that I am proud of Australia's universities. The minister is proud of Australia's universities. The government is proud of Australia's universities. We have good universities in this country-and so we should-because good universities are the hallmark of a civilised society. Let me restate the government's fundamental objective: to have more students, to have better paid staff and to have universities which have an even more honoured place in our society. Let me remind members opposite of the words of former Senator Peter Walsh, who said: Whatever flaws other proposed changes may havereferring to the government's budget package for higher educationthis is better public policy. The Government should stick to it and the Senate should pass it. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. Message from the Governor General recommending appropriation announced. Consideration in Detail Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.  a.m.)-by leave-I move: (1) Schedule 1, items 1 and 2, page 3 (lines 4 to 9), omit the items. (2) Schedule 1, items 9 to 11, page 4 (line 24) to page 5 (line 3), omit the items. (3) Schedule I, items 13 to 21, page 5 (line 13) page 8 (line 17), omit the items. (4) Schedule 1, items 23 to 25, page 8 (line 25) page 11 (line 6), omit the items. (5) Schedule 1, item 27, page 11 (lines 12 and 13), omit paragraph (c), substitute: "(c) guidelines issued under subsection 13(1), sections 20A, 26 or 27, paragraph 35(7)(b) or subsection 36(3).". (6) Schedule 1, items 28 and 29, page II (lines 14 to 18), omit the items. The amendments essentially delete the items from the schedule in the Higher Education Legislation Amendment Bill that give effect to the proposals we object to. They relate to the HECS changes-the differential BECS and the reduction in the repayment threshold-the changes that permit the charging of up-front fees to Australian undergraduates and the changes to the open learning system which, in effect, totally deregulate the scheme and allow the charging of full fees but with only limited scope to assist students financially to cope with that. I make just a few points in response to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Mr Abbott). The parliamentary secretary spoke about the changes that were being given effect to as very minor incremental changes. I guess he was echoing Senator Vanstone's claim that 'it is really just a nick'. He also quoted the Vice-Chancellor of Sydney University, Professor Gavin Brown, who I understand is a distinguished mathematician by training. Professor Gavin Brown's assessment was that the combined effects of the cuts to operating grants, eliminating discretionary funding and not supplementing salary increases will translate into a 15 per cent cut for his institution effective by the year 2000. This is not exactly a nick. The former government attached great priority to maintaining an adequate funding base for our universities. The parliamentary secretary claims that we presided over a fall in funding per student. Perhaps he ought to read Senator Vanstone's speeches where she explicitly repudiates that point in order to try to justify what she is doing. She makes the to point that not only did we increase funding by about 70 per cent in real terms but we mainto tained and, in fact, slightly increased funding per student. Perhaps the parliamentary secretary ought to talk to Senator Vanstone and get the lines straight. The parliamentary secretary referred to the changes in HECS, fees and so forth as mere evolutionary changes. I suggest that the parliamentary secretary read a recent paper by Professor Bruce Chapman, who commented on the government's budget decisions for higher education. Professor Chapman was the architect and designer of the original HECS. He says that these are the most significant changes to be implemented in higher education funding in the past 30 years. Professor Chapman believes the changes will fundamentally transform the system and skew access to higher education toward the rich. I refer the parliamentary secretary to my speech on the second reading debate of this bill, where I quoted specific parts of Professor Chapman's paper. These changes are not minor nicks or little incremental changes to an existing system; these are massive changes that will transform our system for the worse. Reference was made to the impact of HECS on students' participation decisions. When we introduced HECS, we were very mindful of this possibility. Let us contrast the context which we introduced HECS with what is being done now. When we introduced HECS, it was in the context of a green paper and a white paper that laid out a massive expansion of the system and a massive expansion in government funding. It was in that context that we sought to introduce a scheme that recouped part of the cost of that. That is a very different context compared with the current one in which not only is HECS being ramped up by a quantum amount but also the level of public subsidy to universities is coming down in a massive way-not going up as it was under us. When we introduced HECS, we were particularly concerned to monitor and gather research on the impact of its introduction on participation decisions. By and large, the research that we commissioned-most of which was conducted and reported on in 1991-92-showed that at the level we had set it and with the specific arrangements and design, including an income contingent repayment structure, it was unlikely to have an adverse effect on participation decision. That is a very different thing from the quantum jump that is being talked about here. Again, I refer the parliamentary secretary to my speech on the second reading debate where I dealt with these matters in more detail. The final thing I would like to mention is that, in addition to deleting the offending sections from the schedule of the bill, one of the great omissions in this bill is any provision for parliamentary scrutiny of the way these new full fee arrangements are going to work. There already is provision for guidelines on postgraduate fees-and the proposal is to extend that to undergraduate fees-but there is no provision for parliamentary scrutiny. One of the amendments I have moved has the effect of including a provision that will allow the guidelines in relation to fee paying to be disallow able instruments in the parliament which at least will permit some degree of parliamentary scrutiny of those matters. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION LEGISLATION
text: Warringah-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, in Education, Training and Youth Affairs) (10.35 a.m.)-I have a couple of brief comments to make in response to the shadow minister. I really think that it behoves members opposite to see this in context. We are increasing the HECS charge for most courses from roughly $2,500 a year to $3,300 a year-that is, $800 a year. But let us remember that this is a deferred contingent liability. People do not have to pay the extra $800 a year or, indeed, any of the debt until they are in a position to do so-until they are in employment that returns them $21,000 or near enough a year; until they are in a position to move from the lowest tax bracket into the higher tax brackets-a position where the previous government thought they were able to cope with a substantially higher rate of tax. It is a deferred liability; it is a contingent liability. If they never earn the income they are never liable for the debt. Let me repeat what we are doing, because members opposite seem to have wax in their ears: we are taking the Labor Party's system and we are extending it. We are refining it, we are developing it and we are doing so in ways that were recommended by Neville Wran, a former long-serving Labor Premier of New South Wales and a former National President of the Australian Labor Party. The shadow minister made mention of the guidelines. He said correctly that the guidelines are, strictly speaking, beyond parliamentary scrutiny. Obviously, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) is subject to parliamentary scrutiny in her general stewardship of the department; obviously, the government is subject to parliamentary scrutiny in terms of the general accountability of all governments to the parliament and to the people. But, again, what we have done is operate in the same way that the previous government operated, by way of guidelines, in relation to postgraduate fees. All we are doing is taking the way the previous government operated in respect of postgraduate fees and applying it in exactly the same way in respect of undergraduate fees. If it was fair enough for the previous government to operate this way in respect of postgraduate fees, surely it is right and proper Hawker, D. P. M. and reasonable and sensible and fair for us to operate this way in respect of undergraduate fees. Every time members opposite condemn this government, what they are really .doing is condemning their own government. That is why they are so unconvincing. Question put:  agreed to. The House divided.
