Speaker: Dr LAWRENCE
Title: CHILD CARE LEGISLATION
text: I am here this morning because the honourable member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin), our shadow minister, is unable to be here as she has pressing family responsibilities. In my speech in the second reading debate I will be reading from notes she prepared as shadow minister. If time permits, I will make some additions of my own. On behalf of the shadow minister, I move: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House: (1) deplores the Government for abolishing operational subsidies for community-based long day care centres which will have the effect of increasing the costs and reducing the quality of child care for parents using these centres; and (2) condemns the Government for breaking its election promise not to means test the Childcare Cash Rebate". Let me make it clear at the outset that the Labor Party opposes large parts of the bill. The Labor Party opposes the abolition of operational subsidy for community based long day care centres. We oppose applying a means test to the child-care cash rebate. We oppose giving the Health Insurance Commission an open-ended power to defer making a decision about a claim for that rebate so that if the commission does nothing people will not be paid the child-care cash rebate they are entitled to. This is a power which effectively means that parents using child care for work related purposes are guilty until proven innocent. On 20 August this year the Howard government announced a package of cuts to childcare assistance worth half a billion dollars over the next four years. I have on numerous occasions since 20 August made the views of the Labor Party known in relation to these changes. I have said on numerous occasions that the cuts to child care alone pay for almost all of that part of the family tax initiative which gives extra assistance to single income families. I have said on numerous occasions that these cuts are effectively a direct transfer from two income families to single income families, not necessarily those on lower income either. People have told me that the message from the Howard government is quite clear: that women should not be in the work force; women should be at home looking after their children. Let me tell you that people-women, parents-do not like this message. Families where both parents are in the paid work force, where child care is a necessity, are already under pressure in their daily lives. It is not always an easy choice. The jobs at home still need to be done. But, even though it is often a hard decision for both parents to go out to work, this is in the 1990s what most people want. Forty-four per cent of mothers with young children are now working-some 400,000 women-and the number continues to rise. Far from supporting families in the choices they make, this government is effectively taking away some of their options. The combination of the Howard government's changes to child care and the introduction of the family tax initiative with its bias to single income families will clearly distort the choices that families make in the future about how they organise their lives. Analysis of these changes made available to me shows that perhaps the biggest disincentive for partnered women to re-enter the work force is the cost of child care. For example, in a family where the husband is on $25,000 a year with one child in child care, a woman earning between $10,000 and $15,000 will retain less than half of her pay after paying tax, child-care costs and the costs of working. A woman with three children pays considerably more in child-care costs than she pays in income tax. This can result in her retaining as little as 15 to 20 per cent of her earnings. The combination of the family tax initiative and these cuts to child care are a serious disincentive to women who want to enter the work force or stay in the work force. This is political correctness Howard style. But today I want to take the debate further. Today I want to talk not just about what is before us but about how much worse it is going to get for families with children under this anti-family Howard government. I say again, as I have said before in this place, Howard went to the election with a slogan 'For all of us'. Now we know that it is really for some of us and it is not for families who use child care. We already have the blueprint for the Howard government's so-called reform of assistance for families with children in child care. It is set out in the interim report of the Economic Planning Advisory Council's Child Care Task Force 'Future child-care provision in Australia'. The report says: 'The task force has focused on the desirable long-term structure for child care.' What desirable long-term structure does the interim report recommend? It recommends much greater emphasis on payment being made direct to parents themselves rather than to suppliers of child care, means tested financial support in the form of a child-care benefit paid to families for up to 50 hours per week of work related care, up to six hours of care per week where a parent is not in paid work and additional respite care beyond six hours subject to 'gatekeeper' arrangements. It recommends that all existing forms of assistance for child care be abolished, with a possible exception where special needs are involved, and these replaced with a single child-care benefit for low and middle income families. It also recommends that the states and territories should focus on standards, regulation of providers and assistance to services for special needs and that the Commonwealth should focus on payments to parents, research and review. It further recommends that any specific funding of special needs, apart from that through the proposed child-care benefit, should be by block grant from the Commonwealth with supplementation available at the discretion of the states and territories and, finally, that family day care schemes and other similar coordinating bodies for childcare provision be prohibited from placing a cap on fees charged by carers as a basis for eligibility for participating in such schemes. How far are we already along this path? We are a lot further along after the 20 August budget than we were before it. At the moment, child-care assistance is paid to providers while the child-care cash rebate is paid to parents. From January 1998 parents using long day care or family day care will have a choice about having their child-care assistance paid to them or to their service provider. There is not so far to go before this choice is available to families using other kinds of child-care services, like out of school hours care and occasional care. It is not far to go to remove the choice and make the only option available that of having all forms of assistance for child care paid directly to the parents. What this means is that child-care providers lose their guarantee of a regular cash flow. Service providers and the children they care for become vulnerable to interruptions in the continuity of care. As the Creche and Kindergarten Association of Queensland says in its submission to the EPAC Child Care Task Force: 'This proposal is a recipe for disaster.' At the moment, child-care assistance is means tested and the child-care cash rebate is paid free of a means test. From April next year a means test will apply to the child-care cash rebate. If this measure is implemented we will already be at the recommended position of the task force-that all assistance for child care be means tested. Once it is means tested at this level, it is a relatively easy step to make the means test stricter and stricter. At the moment there is no cap on the number of hours for which child-care assistance can be paid and neither is there any requirement for the care provided to be work related. The Howard budget changes this, too. From April next year a 50-hour cap will apply for child-care assistance-again, just as the task force recommended. We should remember that it was an interim, not a final, report. The 50-hour cap is of grave concern to child-care providers in both the community and the private sector. It takes away the centres' capacity to respond flexibly to parents' needs. Much has been made about flexibility in the new industrial relations legislation, yet we have child care now unable to respond flexibly. Some parents start work at 7 a.m. and finish at 4 p.m. Others start work at 9 a.m. and finish at 5.30 p.m. To cater for all parents a centre needs to stay open at least between 7 a.m. and 6 p.m. As Community Child Care Victoria has said, families requiring care at either end of the day or during off-peak times-and a lot of people work that way these days-will either have to pay a very large premium or not be able to find a service at all. It is not much of a further step to limit child-care assistance to six hours of non-work related care, which again is what the task force has recommended. When this happens I will not hesitate to remind you of the coalition's vociferous objections to Labor's measure to impose a 12-hour cap on childcare assistance for non-work related care. Their words will clearly come back to bite them. In the light of these changes, I do not think it is unreasonable to describe the task force's interim report as a blueprint for the future. We are already seeing it. The government is already well on the way to full implementation of its recommendations-before the ink has even been put to paper on the final report of the task force. It is fair to say that everyone in the childcare sector is opposed to these changes. Hundreds of parents from centres associated with the Australian Confederation of Child Care have written opposing them in these terms: My family is very disappointed that the newly elected government now wants to slash both the child-care assistance and cash rebate. We feel let down and misled and we join thousands of families around Australia in calling for the government to reverse the decision to abolish the $30 disregard and to include fringe benefits when assessing care assistance percentages. They object to 'the continued practice of indexing child-care assistance' and so on. This is one of the private provider organisations. They have written to members, including me, opposing these changes. Similarly, the Australian Federation of Child Care Associations makes it plain in its submission to the EPAC inquiry that it is opposed to the changes and very clearly indicates that it has concerns about a number of the recommendations made. It considers that the recommendations of the interim report, some of which have been implemented in the 1996 budget, 'will undermine the high standard of child care that is currently available for all families'. Again, this organisation represent the private providers. Of course, the National Association of Community Based Child Care Centres are also very strongly opposed and have let all members know of that opposition. The unions representing the staff are opposed, local government are opposed and thousands of parents are opposed to these measures. But the government are ignoring them. The government apparently only listen to the market drum. I make the point that the organisation representing the community based centres has run an excellent campaign pointing out the views of parents and their objections to what the government is doing. But the government is ignoring them, despite the fact that the shadow minister has obtained 8,000 signatures from various members of parliament signed by their constituents and a further 10,992 directly from parents who use child care. The major weakness in the task force recommendations, apart from those I have already mentioned, and in the policy of the government is that there is no strategy at all to address the supply side of the child-care equation. There is no strategy to address issues like the availability, quality, supervision, training, regulation, standards and wages. The government simply expects the private sector to deliver 20,000 new child-care places a year over the next few years. How and why is not spelt out. As the Community child- Child Care Victoria response to the report points out most eloquently: The report assumes that the provision of subsidies to individual consumers will allow them to negotiate their own child care arrangements and that this will result in a more diverse, flexible and responsive system. The report proceeds on the assumption that market forces will expand availability to meet demand and increase consumer choice in a competitive environment. Without compromise to quality or workers conditions, this will create a more efficient and effective system of services ... The simple nature of this proposition, from which the recommendations of the report flow, is breathtaking and absurd ... Ironically, it would move itthat is, children's servicescloser to the United States model, which is regarded as one of the worse and which has created entrenched problems of poor quality, low wages, unequal access and high indirect costs. This bill abolishes the operational subsidy for community based long day care to 'encourage services to become more efficient and cost competitive with the private sector'. This is the level playing field argument of the economic rationalists. This is the argument put by the report of the National Commission of Audit. This is also the argument that conveniently forgets that community based long day care services provide additional services to those provided in the private sector-more places for babies, more places for children with special needs, more highly qualified staff, more meals and extended opening hours, to name just a few, which are very important in disadvantaged areas, such as those which exist in my electorate. Do not get me wrong: the private sector does these things, too, but on the whole the community based sector, because of its operational subsidy, can and does do more. You ask the parents-they have not often been able to find places in the private sector, and go to community based centres. Let me remind you, too, that the operational subsidy for community based long day care centres is being abolished in spite of the reassurances given by the coalition to childcare providers before the election. The government was very clear about this. On 28 February, three days before the election-and this shows the audacity of the governmentDavid Kemp, the then shadow minister for employment, training and family services, wrote to the Australian Early Childhood Association as follows: ... the [Coalition] policy also states our continuing support for the community-based long day care sector, and we regard the operational subsidy as one of the key supports of that sector. The Coalition has no plans whatever to change the operational subsidy. So much for their word! Many of the people sitting opposite will be embarrassed by this complete reversal of coalition policy-and they should be. They went out and sold themselves on the basis that this would not occur. Many will have had representations from their local community based child-care centres seeking their opposition to the abolition of operational subsidies, as we on this side have had. Many of these representations have pointed out the effects of the abolition of the subsidy on their centres, especially in terms of the increased costs that parents will have to bear. I will return in a moment to the effects in my own electorate, because they are substantial. The shadow minister says that she has had thousands-literally thousands--of letters on this issue. I think it is worth noting that she says: As I have said elsewhere, I have received more letters on this issue than the opposition as a whole received on gun control. That is how important families regard it. The government cannot tell us now how many of these community based centres will close or where they will close, but they will close certainly. The government cannot tell us how many of these centres will have to pass on the effects of this measure to parents in the form of increased fees. The government cannot or will not tell us how many parents will pay more for their child care in child-care costs and most certainly in payment for food, nappies and so on. So, to the extent that the centres do not do it, they will have to pick it up themselves. Most centres that I have spoken to estimate that fees will rise by between $20 and $25 per week per child. And that is not counting the other changes which add additional costs. There will be community based centres in this country which, because of the abolition of operational subsidies, will start sending notices home to parents saying, 'Fresh fruit can no longer be provided for morning and afternoon tea; please send it with your child,' or they will say that meals can no longer be provided. There will be community based centres which, because of the abolition of the operational subsidy, will have to send home notices saying, 'We can no longer provide a nappy service; please send disposable nappies.' As the shadow minister for the environment, I am not particularly keen about that. There will be more children for staff to look after-in some cases no more, because the centres will close-because there will be fewer staff. There is no doubt in my mind that parents will pay more for the same service or the service they will pay for will be a lesser one. The government has the really hare-brained idea that this is efficiency. They equate poorer quality, more children per staff member, poorly qualified staff and lesser services with efficiency-a funny definition. Many of the parents I have spoken to since the budget have told me that they made a careful and considered choice to use community based long day care centres for their children's sake-a careful and considered choice and their choice, not the government's. They, unlike the government, recognise the value of the sense of community that these services engendered and they appreciate the fact that society as a whole thinks it is important to invest in the future of the children. These are, after all, largely parent controlled or local government controlled centres. Like our investment in public education and public housing, public investment in child care recognises our collective obligation to provide the best for our children. These parents well realise that the abolition of the operational subsidy is the Howard government taking that choice away from them. Thousands have signed petitions to this effect. Many members will be aware of the skydiving grandmother, Fiona Dunbar, who brought drawings from many children and their families to members of this parliament. I hope members have taken the opportunity to think about that gesture. What transitional assistance is the government going to provide to make sure that these centres share in the government's love affair with the market? Every community based long day care centre in the country will be able to engage a consultant-they were advertised recently in Western Australia-to advise them on how best to compete in the new environment, at $3,000 per consultation. The expertise resides in the centres. No-one outside the centres knows how to run them better than the people who currently run them. I might ask members opposite and members of the department: who will be doing this? The operators of child-care centres in the community based sector are vastly insulted by the way this is being conducted. Somebody with lesser expertise than themselves will be paid $3,000 to tell a centre to find more children to care for, to sack a staff member, to replace current staff with less qualified staff, to stop providing meals or fresh fruit for morning teas, to stop providing special treats like a movie or a visit to the zoo, to stop buying in a nappy service, to replace toys and children's books every five years instead of two, and so on. They can figure that out for themselves, horrible though it may be. While Senator Vanstone is cutting labour market programs for the unemployed, Minister Moylan is establishing them for highly paid consultants. The opposition will be moving amendments to the bill to omit item 18, which applies a means test to the child-care cash rebate. In its election manifesto, the coalition said: The Coalition has long supported the recognition of the costs of child care associated with ment. Again, I underline this: A Coalition government will maintain the nonmeans tested childcare cash rebate. So what do we see in the budget? The rebate is abolished, without so much as an explanation or an apology. Child care, as the coalition apparently readily agreed before the election, is a legitimate work related expense. I note that in a speech well after that time the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, Senator Newman, also conceded that it was a legitimate work related expense. Yet it is now being means tested. It is a work related expense irrespective of the amount paid for that work. On the coalition's logic, why shouldn't highly paid men who claim tax deductions for expensive tools, or lawyers who claim for their professional libraries, be subject to a means test? Why are we not cognately debating a bill to introduce a means test on these tax expenditures? The opposition will not stand back while the Howard government breaks its election promises and we will not stand back while it breaks this one. The opposition will not stand back while the Howard government tells some single income families that they are more deserving of assistance than other kinds of families. We are well aware that the Australian people are relying on us to hold the Howard government to its promises. Today we are demonstrating that we mean what we say. We are doing precisely what we said we would do. We are holding the government to its promises and will continue to do so on behalf of all Australians. That concludes the speech that the shadow minister asked me to give on her behalf. I still have a little time, so I want to make some specific references to my own electorate of Fremantle. I think it is important for all members of this House to have a good hard look at how these changes actually affect their constituents. I have taken the trouble-as I know many members have on our side-to go out to the child-care centres in my electorate, both the private and the public ones, to ask employthem what are the likely effects of these changes on the charges they will have to make or the quality of care they provide. I must say it is not a pretty picture. When you take half a billion dollars out of a service like child care, it hurts. It hurts families who can ill afford to be hurt. One of the things that the organisation representing the community based centres has done in Western Australia is to ask parents to indicate to them how their family budget looks now and how it will look after changes to child-care costs. I have here before me one such example. This is a family where there are two adults and two children in child care. At the moment the family income is $743 a week. The childtransfers care cost they pay is $87. They have gage of $255. They have fixed household payments-rates, water, petrol, car maintenance, gas, electricity, telephone, insurance for house contents, car and health-of $290. What is left after all of that at the moment is $111 a week for everything else-food, clothes, pharmaceuticals, the family's needs. What happens with these changes, which will have to be passed on to the operational subsidy in particular, and the other changes that are part of this bill? For the family the same income of $743-there is no suggestion they are going to be paid more-childcare costs escalate from $87 to $132 a week. Assuming their mortgage repayments stay the same-they may diminish slightly but not enough to make up that gap-and that there is no escalation in their fixed household payments, so they are still $290, that family will have left $66 a week for clothes, pharmaceuticals and, as the person who has put forward this budget describes it, a life: entertainment, movies. That is $66 a week two adults and two children. As this constituquality ent describes it, very ironically, 'hard one day, impossible the next'. And this is government that talks about its concerns for families. Similarly, a single parent with two children, one of them under two, at the moment working part-time, getting an income of $290. She gets a part pension and a family allowbase ance. After she has paid the mortgage, the gas, the electricity and so on, she has $50 week left for everything else-for food and clothes and shoes. She says in relation to clothes and shoes, 'Only if I from donations.' She is in an extraordinary position already. When you look at what is going to happen to her, there is a very significant increase in <;:hild-care costs which will almost completely obliterate that $50 a week. I would think that mother will throw up her hands and say, 'I cannot continue to work. I cannot continue to provide for my family. I will have to simply move and become a full pensioner in order to provide any kind of decent income support for my family.' I think the government has not looked at the cost of those inevitable that will occur when individual a mortfamilies have to make that decision. I will give another example provided by one of the parents I met at the child-care centre. She is a nurse, working at the moment from Monday to Friday. Her husband works in the shipbuilding industry, a very rapidly growing industry, at Fremantle, south of Perth. He is a tradesman. Between them, with their two children in care, they earn a reasonable income but things are very tight, as they are for many of these families with mortgages with and the fixed costs that they cannot avoid. With their two children in care, the mother will now have to change her working time to the weekend so that the father can look after the children. She will now work Saturday, Sunday, Monday and Tuesday so that she has to have the children in care only for two days. The husband comes home at the end of a hard five-day working week and acts as the childcare provider for the weekend. Apart from the fact that those parents will rarely see one for another, the impact on the children and the of their lives will be very substantial. That story is a very distressing one but not a uncommon. When I looked at the City of Fremantle's child-care centres, of which there are three, they provided me with information that shows, in some cases, that unless they is can find some subsidy from somewhere else-Fremantle Qoes not have a very big rate and it is not a very big city-they will have to pass on all of these costs directly to a the parents, close the centres or in some way contract them out, which is something they her are very reluctant to do because they have a can't get them social conscience. Take the example of a single parent with one child under two in care full time. At the moment, the City of Fremantle is charging full fees for a week of $159.75. Assuming that the single parent is on a full subsidy, means that at the moment the parent is paying $49.35. From 1 January there will be an increase in fees-in the pipeline because of negotiated wage increases and the normal cost increases while, incidentally, child-care - assistance will be frozen-which will mean that costs will go up to $55.60. After the changes to be introduced on 1 April, a parent will have to pay $72.70, and by 1998 when the final changes are introduced the parent's costs will be up to $83.70. That is a 41 per cent increase in child-care costs over that time for a single parent with one child in care. Similarly, a single parent with a child over two finds that she or he has a 43 per cent increase in child-care costs. A single parent with two children in full-time care will be financially crippled because they end up paying $154 a week in child care, which is a 48 per cent increase, almost doubling the amount they currently pay. These are not fanciful figures. These are figures provided to me by Fremantle Children's Services. That is what they estimate they will have to pass on to parents unless they can substantially change, first of all, the staff in their centres so that they pay less. But, from discussions with them, it is clear that, even if they were able to sack all their long-term staff who have provided continuity of care for the children, they still will not be able to significantly reduce the additional impost on parents. They are now confronted with the very harsh possibility that these centres will have to close. These centres belong to the community. These centres were set up with taxpayers' funds and ratepayers' funds. Parents assist in their management, and care very much about them. In the case of Fremantle, they were set up at a time when it was not fashionable to provide support for parents. They are amongst the longest standing and longest serving childcare centres in this country. Yet they are being told that they have to close. The effects on parents of these changes are inevitable. The preliminary estimates of a survey of child-care centres in Western Australia which is being undertaken-not by that me but by the child-care centres themselvesshow that between 47 and 48 per cent of client parents are on full fee relief. So all of these additional charges go straight to the parents; they have to be met by them. These are people sufficiently poorly off that they need full fee relief. Yet they are the ones who will be hit hardest by this measure. On behalf of the women and the families of Australia, I protest. On behalf of the families in my electorate, I protest. And on behalf of the taxpayers of this country, I protest. (Time expired) Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mrs Sullivan)-Is the amendment seconded?

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: CHILD CARE LEGISLATION
text: I second the amendment.

Speaker: Mr BRADFORD
Title: CHILD CARE LEGISLATION
text: I enjoyed listening to the member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence), both the speech she read from the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin) and her own comments. The sorts of stories she was relating to us about families who, in her estimation, are being adversely affected by some of these changes are stories that members on both sides are bound to hear. But let me put some of the decisions that the government has taken, as with this Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill 1996, in context. Let me sheet the blame home to where I believe it belongs. When we were elected to government we were left with a financial mess of gigantic proportions. We were faced with solving a problem that amounted to what we called a black hole of some $8 billion. Whose fault was that? It was the fault of the former Labor Party government of this country which went on a spending spree that lasted for years in a determined effort to prop up its electoral popUlarity. On 2 March, the Australian people, wisely, took the view that it had to come to an end; that we could not go on spending on programs that were not achieving their objectives. Today, the sorts of examples that the member for Fremantle is giving us are not the fault of this government but the fault of the previous government that left us with an enormous financial problem. I regret that the solutions responsibly put forward by this government in the budget will cause pain across the Australian community. But, in the end, it has to be done. We were given ajob by the electorate to do something about the problem. I believe that the government's approach to solving that problem has been fair. It has had to be tough, but it has been fair, and the pain has been fairly evenly spread across the Australian community. In the end, the changes that we are making in this particular area will mean that the pain will be borne most by those who can afford to pay. That is the proposition and the context in which some of these changes have to be considered. If we had not been faced with the financial problem, obviously some of these decisions would not have been made. If we were not faced with some of these problems, some of these unpalatable sorts of decisions would not have been made. I want to put very clearly at the outset of my response to the member for Fremantle that this legislation and the other budgetary lation that will come forward are the fault of the previous government. It is no good opposition members getting up in here and giving examples, because we can all do that. I have community based child-care centres in my electorate, and I am having to face now as a member of the government some of the concerns-I think not unreasonable concerns-that the people are expressing to me. I could stand up in this place this morning and give some of the same examples that the member for Fremantle has given. In the end, we as a country have a problem. The government will go about solving that problem responsibly by cutting into a lot of the programs that were set up by the former government. Those programs were created to solve unemployment and other problemsproblems which, incidentally, the former government had also created. As those programs failed, the money was wasted. So we are also faced today with solving that problem, and it is unfortunate that many people will suffer to some extent as we attempt to do that. As we solve that problem, the good news is that after the pain there will be gain. There will be substantial gain for Australian families. In taking a responsible fiscal position, the government will ultimately deliver. For example, since the budget, the government has delivered lower interest rates. The effect of lower interest rates for the average family with an average mortgage is a considerable saving. At the last estimation, that saving, in view of the recent drop in housing mortgage interest rates, was in the order of $100 a month. I believe that the best thing we can do for Australian families is to be responsible. We can cut spending, which we have set about doing, without increasing taxes-because that was our pre-election commitment-and ultimately deliver long-term sustainable growth in the Australian economy. That will benefit families. In the meantime, as I have said, there is to be an element of pain spread across the community, but hopefully directed mostly at those who can afford to pay. The opposition amendment that has been moved legisstates that the House: ... deplores the Government for abolishing operational subsidies for community-based long day care centres ... As I said, I think there are elements of the government's decision which are regrettable. I should declare an interest in this, because my youngest child attends such a centre. It is a very well run centre. It is very reasonably priced; I ought to say that is one of its most appealing benefits. My wife makes a regular contribution to it. That is the arrangement; it is a parent controlled community based childcare centre. In my analysis of the outcomes, the extent to which there will be additional costs-and there will be, as the operational subsidy is removed-is being overstated. The sorts of examples that were given-such as that the centres will not be able to provide nappies or fruit-were also exaggerations. At our kindergarten, the children take their own fruit and so on. I think there is an element of exaggeration, whilst I accept that there will be some cost. In the end, the government believes that this move will lead to a better child-care sector and a more competitive sector. We heard from the member for Fremantle a lot of the left-wing ideologies which she is well known for. It is mostly discredited ideology, I observe, that says that markets do not work and competition will not work. In the end, we believe there will be a more competitive child-care sector and a better quality childcare centre as a result of many of the initiatives in the legislation. The second part of the amendment that was moved was that the House: . . . condemns the Government for breaking its election promise not to means test the Childcare Cash Rebate. I need to also put that particular matter in context. The government will actually spend $5 billion on child care over the next four years. The child-care cash rebate will remain available for all eligible families regardless income, but it will be reduced from 30 per cent to 20 per cent for families earning above the new family tax initiative cut offs, which is $70,000 for one-child families plus $3,000 for each additional dependent child. That will mean there will be very little change for 85 per cent of families. For example, a family earning $75,000 per annum with one child may face a reduction in the rebate of less than $10 per week. As I said, the government has largely delivered on its election promises in respect of child care. Where there are some minor changes, they were done in the context of the budgetary situation which we faced. I want to make it very clear that I believe the government is committed to delivering equitable, affordable, flexible and high quality child care to Australian families. That is being demonstrated by what we have done since we were elected to government. The member for Fremantle, who was reading the member for Jagajaga's speech, also talked about the 50-hour cap and was critical of that. She said that when we were in opposition we opposed the former government's intention to impose a 12-hour cap on non-working parents-as we did. She made the suggestion in some respects that that was hypocri tical. Let me turn that around. If the previous government were in favour of a 12-hour cap on non-working parents, surely they can hardly oppose the concept of the 50-hour cap which we intend to impose. Fifty hours of child care available for eligible families, largely at taxpayers' expense, is substan-ial. I think there is every argument that that IS a very reasonable limitation. To argue that it has taken away the ability of child-care centres-and it is mainly commercial centres that we are talking about in this instance-to respond flexibly is just not the case. It is interesting that the EPAC interim report, which the member referred to and which I think is a very worthwhile contribution to the debate on child care-we are yet to see its final report-recommended a sixhour cap on the availability of child care for non-working parents. I think it is inevitableof and I assume that the former government would support this-that, when we do deal with that EPAC report's recommendations, there will be, I think quite correctly, a fairly substantial cap placed on the availability of child care for non-working parents. The whole issue of child care has been one of the philosophical battlegrounds of the 1990s. It is an emotive issue, obviously, and it is one on which there will be differences of opinion in this place. I have been, and. I wi.ll continue to be in the speeches I make In thIS House on the subject, very critical of the way the current system has developed. It is a system that has been largely driven by bureaucrats for a very long time and largely, I need to say also, by feminist bureaucrats. It is a system that has been driven by supply rather than demand. In the arrangements we now propose and in the broader context of other changes we are making in family policy, we want to deliver to families more control and more choice as far as their own child-care arrangements are concerned. We want to encourage competition and encourage the services that are provided to be more responsive to families. What the member for Fremantle appeared to be arguing for when she spoke about the status quo is that the system should somehow be dri ven by the other side-in other words, that the provider's needs should be considered as somehow paramount in this rather than the family's needs. That is demonstrably wrong. Surely, if we are talking about the provision of services to families, then it should be the families that drive the demand for child care, not the opposite. The member for Fremantle, reading the shadow minister's speech, seemed to be arguing for the opposite. That is what we are turning around. We want to have a child-care sector-there is no disagreement about the need for it in today's modem society-that is responsive to the demands and needs of those modem families. As I said, we have had something of a war raging over child care on at least a philosophical level for many years. On one side there were the Eva Coxes of this world who seem to make pronouncements which effectively disparage women who choose to stay home and take care of their own children when the children are young. Ms Cox seems to say that these women can make that choice-she is not going to argue against choice because it is a proposition that is unarguable-but they should not be asking the government for any money if they want to make that choice. In other words, give them a Clayton's choice-force them out into the work force if you can. The underlying philosophy that we see from those extreme views is that women ought to be in the work force and, if they are not in the work force, they are not making a measurable contribution to our gross domestic product. Women like my wife, who has chosen to stay home and raise our children, get from the government by virtue of what used to be the dependent spouse rebate-the name was changed because the language was politically incorrect-the sum total of $32 a week for working 14 hours a day, seven days a week. The whole system discriminates against those women who have chcsen to stay out of the work force or, indeed, those husbands who have made the choice because it suits their family arrangements best. Yet those women who make that choice and stay home clearly save the government a considerable amount of money because they are caring for .their own young children and in the long term make an enormous contribution to our society. The sad fact is that, despite the statistics the member for Fremantle produced, which distort the real situation, both partners are forced to work because of economic circumstances. One partner in a relationship would choose to stay out of the work force if it were a financially viable option. The situation has militated against that for too long. I am pleased that this government has set aboutnot rushing like a bull at a gate, but slowly through the family tax initiatives that we have taken, in respect of some aspects of this legislation and the ongoing debate which will follow the final report of the EPAC task force-winding back that feminist dogma which has been thrust down our throats by the previous government for so many years. On the other side of the argument have been organisations such as the Australian Family Association, which has long called for a homemakers allowance which will provide a realistic alternative to both parents being conscripted into the work force. That proposition is a very appealing one for some of the reasons I have already said, not the least because, quite clearly, if parents were unable to make a proper choice about one of them remaining out of the work force to take care of young children, then, theoretically-and I think in practice-that would have some impact on the number of unemployed, particularly young people, who cannot find any work in the workplace at all. It would also address what I think are some serious inequities that exist-and I do not think there are government solutions to them-when you observe that in some families both of the parents are working full time and in other families neither is. I think this is a basic inequity that can be solved not by direct government intervention but by policies that are effectively family-friendly and that in practice allow families to make the sorts of choices that they really would want to make if it were not for the fact that they were almost proscribed from doing so. Therefore, except for the expenses involved with the Australian Family Association's suggestion, I think that philosophically direction we ought to take. In fact the government has already embarked on that direction by virtue of the family tax legislation that we have brought in that will give parents a greater choice. So the child-care industry has grown in response partly to demand but more so because the government policies we have experienced in recent years have driven it. It was seen by the former government as a politically correct cause. It was seen as an opportunity to win votes by pandering to the extreme feminist agenda, and it has facilitated the entry of women into the work force in increasing numbers, mainly because a lot of them did not have any choice about it. In fact, in south-east Queensland where my electorate is based there is an oversupply of child-care positions-we have too many private childcare centres. For a while there they were like comer stores; they were springing up all over the place. That was driven by the system which has been in place now for so many years. I could go on at some length about a number of aspects, but the underlying philosophy that I and I believe this government subscribes to is that in the end parent care is good for children and that children who receive optimal parent care do very well because of it. This legislation has some benefits. It has some downsides in terms of additional costs, but the blame for that rests squarely with the previous government which left us with a budgetary problem that ultimately, in the interests of Australian families, we had to solve. I believe we have done that responsibly and fairly, and that we have spread the pain across the Australian community equally. (Time expired) Debate (on motion by Mrs Bishop) adjourned. Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: ADDITIONAL RESPONSES
text: Mr Speaker, I seek the indulgence of the House. During question time yesterday and in a subsequent press statement yesterday afternoon the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Crean) attempted to suggest that I was in breach of the guidelines on ministerial responsibility because of my shareholding in a company named Ralsten Pty Ltd. There is no substance whatever in these PAIRS allegations made by the opposition. I have been a shareholder of Ralsten for many years. That has been a matter of public record. My shareholding has always been publicly declared in my register of members' interests. In April this year, following the election, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) issued 'A guide on key elements of ministerial responsibility'. At page 10 of the guide it says: Ministers are required to resign directorships in public companies and may maintain directorships in private companies only if such companies operate, for example, a family farm, business or portfolio of investments and if retention of the directorship is not likely to conflict with the minister's public duty. The guidelines permit in certain circumstances ministers to retain directorships in a private company. Nevertheless, in April this year, following my appointment as the minister, I resigned as a director and chief operating officer of this company. The guidelines go on to say: Ministers are required to divest themselves of all shares and similar interests in any company or business involved in the area of their portfolio responsibilities. Ministers are not precluded from making investments on the stock market or other financial and trading markets, but they should not operate as traders and should exercise careful personal judgment in respect of these transactions. I am no way involved in the activities of the company. The operations of the company are completely independent of me. Its activities continue, but without my personal involvement and in accordance with the guidelines I have just quoted. Mr Crean-You can't be serious!

I have just been advised that the Main Committee has operations. Mr Leo MCLeay- Mr Speaker, I seek your indulgence. This division went till five past one. The Main Committee does not normally meet after 1 o'clock. If the government wants to have the Main Committee meet after 1 o'clock, the normal practice is that the Chief Government Whip consults with me as the Chief Opposition Whip. I have had no communication from Mr Cadman on this matter. The opposition might be willing to consider the matter but I think we ought to be going through the forms. I cannot see how the Deputy Speaker could have resumed the chair in the Main Committee while the division was going on because that is ultra vires the rules. If he did not resume the chair while the division was going on, the Main Committee should have ceased sitting at 1 0' clock, its norm. So at five past one, when you advised the House that he had resumed the chair, I would have thought you should have been advising the House that he had vacated the chair at 1 o'clock.
