Speaker: Mr MOSSFIELD
Title: CHILD CARE LEGISLATION
text: The Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 proposes to discontinue the operational subsidy for community based long day care centres and to amend the Childcare Rebate Act 1993 to reduce the child-care cash rebate from 30 per cent to 20 per cent for families with one child and with taxable as is incomes lower than $70,000 per annum. This legislation will clearly create hardship for low income working families. It is strongly opposed by the Labor opposition. We are expressing our opposition by moving an amendment in which we say that the House member should indicate that it: (1) deplores the Government for abolishing operational subsidies for community-based long day care centres which will have the effect of increasing the costs and reducing the quality of child care for parents using these centres; and (2) condemns the Government for breaking its election promise not to means test the Childcare Cash Rebate. The legislation turns the clock back 20 years by amending the Child Care Act 1972 introduced by the Liberal-Country Party government of William MCMahon. The 1972 act was introduced in recognition of the increase in labour force participation by women and the subsequent need to provide affordable, quality child care for their children. In hindsight, this was a very noble and far-reaching piece of legislation and it certainly showed a lot of vision in relation to the numbers of women that entered the work force over that period. In her speech, the honourable member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence) quite clearly pointed out the strong opposition to the government's legislation from all sections of the child-care industry-local government, private providers, parents and community based child-care centres. The honourable member made the point that the government's legislation will make the child-care system in this country more like the inefficient system that operates at the moment in the United States of America. Inefficient child-care centres mean unsafe child-care centres. The honourable member for Fremantle also made the point that this legislation breaks the election promise of the government. It will also create enormous hygiene problems and other problems relating to child care. In his contribution, the member for MCPherson (Mr Bradford) conceded that low income people would suffer. He made the point that in his particular set of circumstances he did not require child care. The point I would like to make is that high income people do not need child-care facilities. We are not arguing on behalf of high income people. We are arguing on behalf of two-income working families. They are the people that we are going into battle for with this piece of legislation. The member for MCPherson also gave us the tired old argument that it was all the last government's fault. Sooner or later, the new government has to realise that it is now the government and it has to bring in legislation that will be for the benefit of the people, rather than use the tired old argument that it is overcoming a problem that was created by the previous government. The need for child-care places to assist women in the work force should be recognised. The rate of female participation in the work force has increased from 40.6 per cent in 1972 to 53.4 per cent in 1996. This increase has been particularly high in the 25 to 59 year age group. The establishment of community based child-care centres gives parents and local communities substantial control over the child-care services in their area. The member for MCPherson made the point that parents need to have control over their children's child-care facilities. This is what now happens with community based child-care centres. It is important that parents are involved in the management committee of child-care centres as it ensures that the centre is responding to the needs of the children. It is anticipated that the removal of the operational subsidy will save the government $118.4 million in three years. To assist community based long day care centres to adjust to the removal of the operational subsidy, the government has allocated $8.3 million over the next four years. This funding is intended to encourage community based long day care centres to hire consultants to help them to restructure their services and improve efficiency without raising fees. This appears an impossible objective without affecting the quality and standard of child care. Clearly, I would suggest that this is a waste of taxpayers' money. To be allocating this sort of finance for consultants is not warranted when in most cases they would actually lack the experience and the expertise that the child-care centres themselves currently have. The issue of child care-in particular, the operational subsidy of long day care centreshas been a matter of considerable public discussion in the electorate of Greenway for some time. The electorate contains a number of fast growing residential areas where two income families reside and more young families are moving in at a rapid rate. There is, therefore, an urgent need for family support services, particularly child care, to allow both parents to take part in either full-time or part-time work so that the family's budget can be balanced. The previous federal Labor government was well aware of this need across the nation and during its term of office child-care places increased from 46,000 in 1983 to 270,000 in 1996. Child-care places were given a high priority in western Sydney under the Labor government. As at 15 September 1995 there was a total of 11,369 Commonwealth funded day care places available in western Sydney. This represents 361 places for every 1,000 children in the region compared with the New South Wales average of 326 places per 1,000 children. Under Labor, Blacktown, in particular, had the highest relative level of long day care supply in western Sydney. In spite of this major contribution, the target population has increased considerably since the 1991 census and many child-care services still have significant waiting lists. Despite the record of the previous Labor government, my Liberal opponent in the March elections, who was a working mum with two young children, tried to score some political points out of the child-care issue. My opponent was quoted in a press article in January of this year as saying: Affordable child care was a basic right of all parents. With record numbers of women now in the work force, the pressure and demand for childcare positions only continues to grow. I agree wholeheartedly with my Liberal opponent on that particular issue. Clearly, she felt that this was a good issue to run in that particular election. However, when I was able to reply to her criticism of the Labor government with the government's record in this area, we heard no more from her. We heard no more from the Liberal Party on that particular issue in the election campaign. I do agree with the points that she was quoted as making in the local press. I am sure now she would be bitterly disappointed, as would many other working mums in Greenway, and would be lamenting the reduction of funding for child care announced in the budget. Furthermore, during a debate in Blacktown Council prior to the budget Liberal Party councillors dismissed as rumours plans to remove operational subsidies for community based child-care centres. Labor Party councillors were more on the ball with Councillor Michael Sommerton, when referring to possible cuts in funding, saying: We are at a stage where child care is of complete importance, this is really going to hurt and hurt hard. Blacktown Council was so concerned about the proposed cuts that it called a public meeting. At this meeting, concerned parents were advised that the council operated 25 funded services under its children's services administration-20 long day care centres, three out of school hours programs, family day care and early intervention and ethnic programs. In 1996-97 Blacktown Council was to receive more than $1.5 million in operational funding from the federal government. Any reduction in this funding would have led to either increased fees or a reduction in services. This would place many families in Greenway in an impossible dilemma, with the parents either having to remain at home to look after their kids, increasing their financial burden even further because of having to pay increased fees, or allowing children to become latchkey kids, with all the social problems that this would inevitably lead to. In the cold war period leading up to the budget announcement, numerous phone calls were made to my office by both parents and carers expressing their concern about cuts in funding for child care. I in tum passed these concerns on to the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) by correspondence. While I have spoken principally about my own electorate of Greenway in this debate, there is clearly a national and regional question to be considered. Community based care centres make up a greater proportion of childcare services in rural and remote Australia. This is in part because commercial operators do not perceive that long day care centres are viable in remote areas. The operational subsidy received by community based long day care centres can be used to offset the greater expense of operating these centres in rural areas. The budget provides capital funding intended to ensure that families in rural and remote areas and places of special need have access to child care. However, despite the allocation of funding to help them adjust to the loss of the operational subsidy, community based long day care centres have argued that this will not be sufficient and that centres will be forced to pass on these costs to parents. I think the House would appreciate that, while this is a serious problem in the metropolitan area of Sydney and other major cities, it is an even more extreme and more serious problem in remote and regional Australia. It has been suggested that a low income family with one child under the age of three receiving maximum child-care assistance of $2.30 per hour would, after the child-care cash rebate was factored in, experience a rise in the cost of care for their children from $29.50 to $50.90 per week. Clearly the question arises as to whether community based organisations would consider it worthwhile or feasible to continue operating long day care centres in the absence of this subsidy. While the government may argue that it has made certain provisions in the budget to help single income families, they certainly do not go far enough. With the tax relief to single income families amounting to only $17 a week and with increases in pharmaceutical prescription costs affecting families with chronically ill children, the financial burden on young families still requires both parents to seek full-time employment, particularly middle income working class families. This point was clearly made by Ross Gittins in an article in the Sydney Morning Herald on 22 August, which said in part: The budget's nice bits aren't as generous as they sound. The plan to raise your tax threshold by $1,000 for each dependent child, for instance, is worth just $3.85 per week per head-provided you are eligible, of course. Eligibility for the additional benefit for stay at home mums is very limited, and what starts off at $2,500 turns out to be $9.60 a week. The maximum value of the health insurance rebate is $8.65 a week. Few families would be eligible for all three of these. The Ross Gittins article goes on: Against these pluses you have to set a plethora of higher charges, induding an extra $2.60 per prescription, higher community child care fees and unnamed indirect increases in state taxes and charges and cutbacks that would affect the pockets of migrant families, families with relatives entering nursing homes, families with children receiving Austudy or paying HECS or more. The article by Gittins makes the point that mainstream Australia are the net losers in the first Howard budget. Also, with the changing nature of our culture, many young mothers are desirous of remaining in the work force so as to retain or upgrade their skills to ensure employment opportunities in later life. I have only this week received a complaint from a mother who had high qualifications who had dropped out of the work force to raise her family. She is now having problems re-entering the work force because she lacks recent employment experience and she is being denied the opportunity of enrolling in government funded training programs. I think this is a very serious and major social change that has taken place over the past decades, even prior to the Labor government coming into power. It was recognised by the MCMahon government in 1972 when it introduced this legislation. More and more women want to get into and remain in the work force-either part time or full timeduring the time that they are raising children and certainly with the view of continuing in employment after their children and family have grown up. For that reason, it is very important that the programs the previous Labor government introduced in relation to child care remain intact. I certainly think that this government is turning the clock back, which is going to seriously affect low income working families. For economic and social reasons, the government was obliged, I would have thought, to continue with the operational subsidy for community based child care. I have raised these pre-budget comments by my political opponents, by Blacktown councillors and by the providers of parents using child-care facilities to emphasise the high degree of interest in this issue. Judging by public comment, while there were many major issues in Greenway during the election campaignsuch as road and rail infrastructure, employment, education and health-child care was the major issue in 1996. Therefore, parents will be bitterly disappointed that the Howard government have failed to keep their promise that our world-class child-care system would be safe in their keeping. There is also an industrial consequence to the government's decision to reduce funding for child care. Centres have had to totally rework their budgets. They have had to review their staff numbers with the possibility of having to make a painful decision to downsize. When the issue of downsizing was raised with me by some directors of child-care centres in Greenway, I placed a question on notice to the minister seeking, among other things, information about funding for redundancy. The answer was 'No. The funding of any redundancy package is the responsibility of the service.' In other words, the government cuts the funding and the centres themselves are left to pick up the personal, industrial and economic pieces caused by this unfair budget decision. Let me conclude on a slightly broader note than just the specific child-care issue: the labour force participation of Australian women. I am very pleased to have obtained from the Parliamentary Library-and I must compliment the library on the service they provide to the members; as a new member I have appreciated very much the service that we do get from the Parliamentary Library-a preliminary paper presented to the 25th Annual Conference of Economists in Canberra in September on this important subject. One of those who is working on this excellent and ongoing research and was part-author of the paper is at our own University of Canberra Faculty of Management, Miss Ann Daly. I commend this paper to all memberseven though it is preliminary-as some of the results coming through about working women indicate to me a clear and ongoing need for more, not less, assistance in the child-care area, particularly long day care. Miss Daly's work will, I believe, ultimately prove to be a most vital, valuable tool for those in policy advice areas of government. Again, I commend the paper, which is available here in the Parliamentary Library, to all members.

Speaker: Mrs WEST
Title: CHILD CARE LEGISLATION
text: I am pleased to have the opportunity to rise in this House to repudiate the claims made by some over the removal of operational subsidies to community based long day care centres. Never have I witnessed a greater embellishment of the facts. The level of scaremongering being whipped up in my local community is reminiscent of the farcical arguments raised over the nursing home entry contributions. However, before I set about clearing the record, I will remind the House of the history of operational subsidy. The Child Care Act 1972 was enacted by the conservative government of William MCMahon in recognition of the growing number of women entering the labour force. Operational subsidy was introduced to encourage councils and non-profit community groups to set up long day care centres in areas of need. It is now claimed that the operational subsidy is used by these centres to provide a higher quality of service than private centres. In fact, the manager of one such centre in my electorate of Bowman claimed: Community-based centres like ours provide different services from the private sector. She also added: The extra funding was necessary to keep fees at a lower level and to provide top quality services. The President of the Queensland based Parents for Child Care Group, Frances Snedden, went further by saying: Parents would be shocked by the level of the increased fees. Mrs Snedden also claimed parents using community based care would have to pay between $700 and several thousand dollars extra a year. Mr Deputy Speaker, I will come back to these claims a little later. I do not suggest that the changes being proposed in this bill will not cause some waves but all change brings some reaction and if we rejected change for this reason alone this country would go nowhere. However, I do dispute the accuracy of the claims made recently by the community based sector. The community based sector has claimed that withdrawal of the operational subsidy will force them to drop the standard of their service, force them to increase fees by up $50 per week, force the closure of community based centres and threaten the delivery of high cost care, meaning babies and children with special needs. Let me deal first with the issue of quality of service. As all in the House would be aware, all long day care centres are required to participate in the quality improvement and accreditation scheme. This scheme was introduced to ensure that centres provide the highest level of care and that this care was standardised across the nation. I recently visited the Capalaba Kindergarten and Preschool in my electorate. This is a private child-care facility which has never had a government subsidy. When assessed recently by a reviewer, the centre achieved the highest possible level of accreditation. This was achieved because the staff are dedicated to providing the highest possible level of care to the children in their care. This centre provides many of the services found in community based facilities, with the exception of providing lunches. However, they do provide the added benefit of full tertiary trained staff, something not centres can boast and something which comes at some expense to the providers, yet the fees of this private, unsubsidised child-care facility are comparable to the seven community based centres in my electorate. While the Capalaba Kindergarten and Preschool can be proud of its achievements, I could not say it is unique in the quality of service it provides. I have a number of very good centres in my electorate. I would have to say that all of the centres in my electorate, the majority of which are privately run, provide quality service. In fact, in Bowman I have a total of 3,693 child-care places. Of these, 1,962 places are in private centres while 297 are in the community based centres. While I am not in any way claiming that private centres provide better care than community based centres, I would suggest that these statistics support the statements made by Chris Buck, the President of the Queensland Child Care Centres Association. Mr Buck, a Bowman constituent, was quoted in the local paper as saying that Mrs Snedden's description of the budget measures were alarmist and inaccurate. On the issue of fees, Mr Buck reported that community based centres receive an unfair advantage over privately run centres. He said: The community-based sector needs to look at how the private sector can provide the same services without a subsidy. The same service? This comment intrigued me. How could a centre which has to run at a profit provide the same standard of service, at a comparable or at least similar cost, to one which does not have to make a profit and which gets a $50,000 annual government subsidy? This led me to research both private and community based centres in my electorate. The results were not only surprising but very puzzling. I found out that virtually every centre provided a different service. Some provided care for babies, others did not. Some provided a nappy service, many did not. Some provided cooked lunches, some provided cold lunches, and some provided no lunches at all. Some provided a separate all preschool program run by a fully trained teacher, others did not. Some received a government handout, many did not. Yet they all charged about the same fee. In fact, one of the cheapest was a private centre which provided lunches and a nappy service. On average, the difference between the private sector and the community based sector, in fee terms, was $4. Is it any wonder then that Mr Buck was so vocal in his criticism? He went on to say: There is no justification for the different treatment. Community centres should be substantially cheaper than private ones, but they're not. That was also highlighted by my survey. If the government is paying the community sector $20 per child, why is the sector passing on only $4 to the parents? The community sector has also claimed that centres will be forced to close. This was one issue on which both the private and community sectors agreed-however, for vastly different reasons. The proliferation of child-care centres in my electorate of Bowman is astonishing. It has been described as a calamitous situation and one which will force centres to close. How did this happen? Poor planning is the only response. Labor's ad hoc child-care system, which lacked adequate planning mechanisms, has resulted in an oversupply in some areas and an undersupply in others. Within a two-kilometre radius of my electorate office in Capalaba there are no fewer than six child-care centres. It is for this reason, and not for those claimed by some, that centres will close. The centrepiece of the budget in relation to child care, the national planning framework, will address Labor's failure in this area. In announcing the budget changes, the government put in place a number of measures to assist centres which will lose the operational subsidy. Those measures include: $8.3 million to assist community based long day care centres to overcome the loss of operational subsidies and to obtain financial management advice, something that was agreed to and is welcomed by those needing this assistance; $10.9 million dollars to provide capital funding for new places in areas of need; $12.5 million to ensure that families in severely disadvantaged areas do not lose access to child care; and $31 million to support children with high levels of additional need. The Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) has also indicated that she is more than happy to continue dialogue with the industry to guarantee that people who live in areas of need are not disadvantaged. The government has also announced that it will continue operational subsidies to the tune of $526 million for family day care, occasional care, outside school hours care, multifunctional services and multifunctional Aboriginal children's services, so those latchkey kiddies mentioned by others will not eventuate. The non-means tested child-care cash rebate scheme has also been retained. The rebate remains available to all eligible recipients. However, families who earn more than the new family tax initiative cut-off will receive a 20 per cent rather than a 30 per cent rebate. The government is asking those who can afford it to pay more. This government is concerned with the quality of care available and will ensure that it is affordable to those who need it. The government is also keen to ensure that parents who have placed their children in privately run centres are on an equal footing to those with children in a community based centre. I do not feel this is unreasonable when you consider that 80 per cent of all the children in long day care in my electorate are in privately run centres. I fully support the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill and commend it to the House.

Speaker: Ms ELLIS
Title: CHILD CARE LEGISLATION
text: I rise in support of the amendment moved by the shadow minister for the aged, family and community services, the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin), to the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill 1996. Before I go into detail on the points I want to make on this amendment, I will reflect very briefly on some comments that were made by a previous speaker in this debate, the member for McPherson (Mr Bradford). I was a little confused by the contribution of the member for MCPherson. He seemed to be taking me down a crazy stone path of philosophy and I had a bit of difficulty following him. He said that he understands and regrets the fact that his government has had to make decisions on a financial basis in relation to child care and the costs thereof and that these measures were regretted, but he laid the blame on the mythical $8 billion black hole. At the same time he has a philosophical debate about women who stay at home and women who choose not to, for whatever reason. He quoted Eva Cox and used words like, 'The previous government was pandering to the extreme feminist agenda,' when it was in fact making available to the community child-care access across as many boundaries as possible. When members of the government stand up in this child-care debate to defend the action that is being taken, they really need to get their records and their lines straight. They either believe that they are doing it for a very regrettable financial reason, which I mayor may not agree with, or they agree with it on a purely philosophical basis-a debate I am happy to have with members opposite at any time. But I think it is a bit deceitful to run two arguments so different from each other in the one debate and expect me, a member of the opposition, to accept those reasons when we consider the action that this government is taking in relation to child care. I support the amendment moved by the shadow minister because I believe that the government's proposals will cause significant harm to families in my electorate and others. They represent a clear breach, yet again, of the pre-election commitments of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). Many Australian families will remember that during this recent election campaign the Prime Minister promised the retention of the system of child-care assistance, the retention of the non-means tested child-care cash rebate and 5,500 additional places in family day care. We have to make sure that the people hear us when we say that these commitments have not been kept. Instead, this government has disgracefully slashed $500 million from childcare assistance and is at the same time asking families to make up that difference. These proposals mean that families with kids in care are being asked to give up any benefit they might have obtained from this same government's tax changes. In many cases, families will be forced to pay significantly more in increased child-care costs than they could possibly hope to get back in tax cuts. There can be absolutely no doubt that the proposal to abolish operational subsidies for community based long day care centres will have a dramatic effect on the quality, the diversity and the affordability of child-care services available to families in my electorate of Namadgi. If this legislation is passed, all community based long day care centres will lose their operational subsidy from July 1997. Community based centres form an integral part of the child-care sector. Community based centres take a larger proportion of the very young children. If you look at it carefully, you will see that they take many more young babies who require additional care than the older kiddies. They take children with disability. They take children at risk. In other words, they take a higher proportion of those try to children needing the additional care. The previous speaker, the member for Bowman (Mrs West), should have concentrated on that angle when she was doing a survey of childcare centres in her electorate and been a little more open about what categories she found in different child-care centres. It is these children who will inevitably suffer most from the cuts we are looking at. I am particularly concerned about the future of the eight community based long day care centres in my electorate of Namadgi if these cuts to operational subsidies go ahead. These eight centres alone are currently caring for over 300 children. What the government has to understand and has to hear is that these centres are an important part of our community-they have come from our community originally. The loss of the subsidy will inevitably force these community based centres to reduce the quality of care offered, charge more to parents who can least afford it or, worse still, consider closure. I know that some of them at the moment are going through their range of options. While the Howard government's cuts will mean all Namadgi families must pay more for child care, the effect on those families in the eight community based centres will be much more severe. For example, a Namadgi electorate family earning $35,000 a year with two children in 50 hours care a week will be faced with finding an extra $7.53 a week in a private centre, but if the children are at one of our community based centres that extra cost will be $29.16 a week. Despite the government's claims, a large number of families in my electorate will find that the much hyped family tax initiative will not cover the increased costs that they will have to bear as a result of the measures outlined in the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill that we are debating. I would like to give some further brief examples of the effects on families in my electorate. A Namadgi family on a combined income of $47,000 a year with two children in child care for 50 hours a week will have to pay $14.93 a week more and extra if their children go to community based long day care. The Howard government's family tax initiative gives this same Namadgi family just $7.70 a week, leaving them $7.23 a week worse off. A sole parent earning $28,000 a year and maybe studying one night a week with two kids in child care for 55 hours will have to pay a mammoth $41.69 a week more in a private centre and even more if the children go to a community based long day care centre. The Howard government gives this Namadgi parent only $17.30 a week extra. This parent is, therefore, at least $24 or $25 a week worse off. Previously, Namadgi families had that threshold of $30 per week of income per child that the government exempted when calculating child-care assistance. That threshold does not count any more and will result in lower levels of assistance families. If parents in my electorate work long hours, the Howard government is now saying that they have to pay full costs once child care goes over 50 hours a week. In addition, the government has frozen the amount of childcare payments families can receive for the next two years. At the same time, it is allowing the minimum fee, which Namadgi parents have to pay, to rise. This will increase the between government assistance and the rate actually charged by the centre. I have said it before in this place but it needs to be said again and again: the pathetic efforts of this government stand in stark contrast to the history of achievement of the former Labor government in concert with the community on the question of child care in the past. The introduction of child-care assistaccordingly. ance, the child-care cash rebate and operational subsidies for community based child-care centres are all Labor government initiatives. Labor made child care more affordable and available. This highlights a fundamental difference between our stance and the stance of the Liberal-National coalition. We believe in families having the right to access flexible, affordable, high quality child care. This bill represents the first step towards undoing all of those achievements. The increased child-care costs will almost certainly make many women think twice about reentering or remaining in the work force. When I heard the member for MCPherson earlier on talking about choice, I wondered what he meant when he said it. Another important aspect of this debate that is often overlooked is the desire of the coalition government to hand over to the states and territories responsibility for large areas of health and family services-and we know that debate is running at the moment. This handover has the potential to lead to inequalities in the provision of services, especially in remote or lower income areas, a possible lower commitment to the child-care sector by the state or territory government and differing standards across the country. It often strikes me as inconsistent that members of the government are on one hand to happily passing the responsibility for a number of essential community services and programs to the states and territories, but on the other hand feel quite right in intervening on moral issues-and I will leave that for people to consider. The government's proposed changes to the payment of child-care assistance also look like having unfortunate consequences for the child-care sector. The payment of assistance gap directly to parents, rather than to the childcare centre direct appears certain to lead to centres losing the certainty of funding that they currently have. This decision will also undoubtedly add administrative costs related to gathering funds from parents. At the moment a centre can predict very clearly the budget they are going to have to work with for the coming year and scales of equity go This proposal will hand money to the centres in a very ad hoc and unpredicted fashion. I would like to tum now to the clearest breach of the pre-election commitment contained in this bill: the government's decision to means test the child-care cash rebate. The introduction of the child-care cash rebate by the former government recognised child-care costs as a work related expense and that child-care costs can be a significant disincentive for women thinking about taking up employment. Like other tax concessions for work related expenses, the rebate was not means tested. Despite their promises not to means test the rebate, the government at the behest of the National Commission of Audit have imposed a means test on the rebate. Curiously, the Commission of Audit did not suggest means testing deductions for other work related expenditures such as uniforms and tools. Since the government made public its desire to savage the outstanding existing child-care system my electorate office has been flooded with petitions, letters and telephone calls of complaint. In response to this community outrage, my ACT Labor colleagues and I convened the ACT child-care sector summit to discuss the future of child care with parents, child-care providers and unions. I am pleased to be able to inform the House that as a result of that summit representatives from all parts of the ACT child-care sector were able to reach a united position against the government's proposals. It is important that the House note that the initiative was taken from the floor of that meeting. That meeting represented all sectors within the child-care area: private centres, community based centres, occasional care, after school hours careevery sector was there and a decision was unanimously reached by all those sectors. Firstly, the child-care sector in the ACT, asserts the needs and rights of children should be at the core of all child care and must be the primary concern of child-care policy makers; secondly, supports the rights of all families and their children to have access to quality, affordable work related and non-work related child care as a means of achieving financial and social objectives; thirdly, recognises that all providers have an important role in achieving these goals by providing diversity and choice; fourthly, recognises the professional skills provided by workers in the sector and supports salaries and working conditions commensurate with those skills; fifthly, supports the maintenance and continued expansion of the national quality improvement and accreditation system as a means of enhancing the quality of care provided to children; sixthly, opposes proposed moves to reduce assistance to families by combining child-care assistance with the child-care rebate and alteration of the method of payment; seventhly, opposes the move to means test child-care rebate which was clearly introduced as an alternative to tax concessions on childcare costs and recognises that child care is a work related expense of all working families; eighthly, opposes the reduction or abolition of the operational subsidies to community childcare centres and family day care organisations-this was agreed to prior to the budget and at that time family day care organisations were under threat-and, lastly, calls on the federal government to improve financial assistance and overall funding to achieve the joint objectives of children, families, sector workers and service providers. In conclusion, I firmly believe that the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 takes child care in the wrong direction for the wrong reasons and, therefore, I cannot support the bill in its present form. Furthermore, given the strong opposition to the government's proposed changes within the community, I call on the government to seriously reconsider its position on these changes. It is an important point in this very relevant debate today to try to convince the government that this is not a political campaign. As a local member I do not have to go out into my electorate and whip up the community into a frenzy over child care; in fact, I have to try to calm them down. Opposition to the changes is coming from within the community. I repeat, it is coming from private centres, community centres, occasional care, family day care, the union representing the workers, holiday care and from the after school hours care sector. Every part of the child-care sector is alarmed at what this government is proposing to do to the child-care system in this country, a child-care system which has been built up over many years between government, bureaucracy and community and is now held in the highest regard in the world. I do not for the life of me understand why purely for economic rationalist reasons the child-care sector should be so badly affected. We are not going to sit by and allow a government to get away with this. I can assure you that people on this side of the House will not allow it.

Speaker: Mrs JOHNSTON
Title: CHILD CARE LEGISLATION
text: Canning) (1.57 p.m.)The Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 is a very important issue. I am loath to have to interrupt my speech because of question time, but I will start and make some of the comments that I had intended to make. Child care is very big business today. This year alone Australia will spend around $2.4 billion on paid child care with 60 per cent of that being spent by governments and, not surprisingly, the federal government is the largest contributor. Of the 1.3 million children in Australia who are under the age of four today, 40 per cent are cared for in the home by one parent, a quarter are cared for by friends and relations and the remainder are in some type of formal child care. I found it absolutely astonishing to learn that it has been estimated that a child can spend 12,500 hours in child care, which is only 500 hours less than an entire 13 years of schooling. The long day care centres have become the fastest growing sector of one of the most rapidly developing industries in this country. Analysis has demonstrated that two years ago there were 2,600 centres in operation while today this number has grown to over 4,000. Approximately eight new child-care centres open every week somewhere in this country. As I said at the outset, the child-care business is big business. Seventy five per cent of long day care centres are run privately and for profit. I recently read a very interesting article by Sally Loane called 'The big business of caring for little kids'. In the course of her research for her paper Ms Loane visited many child-care centres around Australia and she said: Private for profit, private work-based or community based, theymeaning child-care centresare as individual and different as the little people attending them. Some, in converted suburban houses resemble the family home, down-at-heel but cheerful. Others are multi-million dollar architecturally designed style palaces. Some community centres are glamorous and glitzy, some private centres are old and stuffy and vice versa. This paints a colourful picture of the childcare industry. It is far too simplistic to say that one type of care is superior to another because it is either privately run or community based. That is why I believe that all childcare centres should operate on the same level with none having any advantage over another.

text: My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Is it a fact that one of the major banks has just announced another cut in its home loan interest rate? What are the benefits for home buyers of such amove?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: It is true that the National Australia Bank announced today interest rate cuts across its entire range of fixed rate home loans. These include a cut of 1.1 per cent-I repeat, a cut of 1.1 per cent-in the one-year fixed rate national tailored home loan. These interest rate cuts come on top of other reductions that have been announced by other home morgage lenders. For example, Aussie Home Loans announced that its variable home rate would fall from 8.65 per cent to 7.99 per cent; FAI announced a reduction in its rate from 8.45 per cent to 7.95 per cent; and Westpac announced a reduction in its first option home loan rate from 8.4 per cent to 7.89 per cent. These reductions, and other reductions, mortmean that Australians are now enjoying the lowest level of home loan mortgage rates for over 20 years. It is very interesting that something that represents unambiguous good news for Australians-whether they vote Labor, Liberal or something else-is the subject of constant interjection from the Labor Party front bench. Isn't it interesting that, whenever the government has got anything to say about something that is good news for the Australian people, all the opposition tries to do is to respond with a cacophony of noise and irrelevant interjections? All the noise, the interjections, all the waving around of sheets of paper by the shadow Treasurer who wants to be noticed and wants to tell his colleagues that he is now back on the job-all of that cannot gainsay the fact that, while you are doing that, Australian home buyers are getting the benefit of the lowest rates for 20 years. That is unalloyed good news for Australian families. There is nothing that resonates more, so far as the living standards of Australian families in the suburbs and in the provinces of this country are concerned, than a cut in home loan interest rates. That is something that goes right to the adequacy of the weekly pay packet. One hundred and five dollars a month-I repeat, $105 a month-has been the value of the cuts in home loan interest rates since we came to power in March of this year.

Speaker: Mrs WEST
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Family Services. Is the minister aware that the drug calcitrol, which is used to treat osteoporosis in postmenopausal women, is not available on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme to treat the same condition in elderly men? What is the minister's response to concerns about this situation?

Speaker: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I am aware of this concern. Calcitrol is available on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme on an authority required basis for established post-menopausal osteoporosis where a fracture has occurred with minimal trauma. Osteoporosis occurs usually in later life-often in women, sometimes in men-where the bones become thinner and much more brittle. On the whole issue of the pharmaceutical benefits system, I probably get a thousand letters a month and 40 per cent of all the mail that honourable members send to me would be about the pharmaceutical benefits system. So I would like to tell honourable members why the system is as it is. In Australia we spend about $2.6 billion on pharmaceutical benefits-that doubled in the last four years; it may double in the next four years-and we fund medication on the basis of scientific evidence, cost-effectiveness and nothing else. That way, we are able to fund the latest and most modem drugs on some sort of orderly basis. There is a pharmaceutical benefits advisory committee that advises me, and I am not able to fund drugs other than on advice by them. It is difficult saying no to people who want certain medications, but the only thing I can think of than a politician making a decision not to give someone a drug is a politician making decisions on who does and does not get them in some sort of way that is not orderly. In the specific case of calcitrol, the drug company Roche has submitted very substantial evidence as to its effectiveness in postmenopausal women, but we do not have the scientific data on its effectiveness in men. In fact, just last week there was a scientific consensus conference in Canberra on osteoporosis which involved kinetions and scientists. Speaker: Mr CAUSLEY
Title: NOES
text: My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The minister will be aware that under present legislation there is a need for review of the structural arrangements of the Australian meat and livestock industries. Given the difficult trading conditions currently facing the industries, what action has the government taken to review the industries structures?

Speaker: Mr ANDERSON
Title: NOES
text: I thank the member for his question. I have today released a report into the meat industry structures. That report and the action that will flow from it form a vital plank in the government's total reform agenda for the very important red meat industries in this country. One of my first actions in coming to government in May was to commission a report into options for new, more effective industry bodies for the meat industry. Today I have launched that report. There has been a great deal of interest in it. I will seek, over the next couple of months, prior to making final decisions and taking recommendations to the government, to consult closely with industry and with government representatives to establish the best way forward. The report goes into a lot more than simply industry structures. It identifies quite a list of policy and program actions for the red meat sector, many of which we are very actively pursuing already. These are issues such as safety and hygiene-a very important area indeed for our consumers here and internationally, for whom the question of food safety is now at the absolute top of their list of priorities; industry adjustment, because under the difficult circumstances the industry now faces adjustment will be necessary; and, in training and education. I would be the first to say that it is an industry that needs a fair bit of training and education across the boardboth sides of the employee and employer divide-if we are to really capture the sorts of improvements that we are going to need in the future. The report also canvasses competition policy and workplace reform. Under the legislation put together so painstakingly and carefully by the Minister for Industrial Relations, it will now be possible for this industry to start to match those of the New Zealanders and the Americans. Returning for a moment to the question of industry structures, the report identifies the need to very carefully consider what might be regarded as appropriate collective functions and what belong to industry sector specific roles in terms of their functions out in the marketplace. Interestingly enough it recommends moving away from statutory authorities, of which there are currently three at the federal level, to corporatisation, because that will give a greater degree of industry ownership, flexibility and a greater commercial focus. It recommends the integration of research and development and marketing and the separation of regulation from service delivery across the nation. All of this will constitute a vitally important link in the ground up restoration of Australia's rural industries, reflecting our ground up rebuilding of the economic and social infrastructure of regional Australia. All of this is in direct contrast to what we saw from the previous government. We have acted very quickly and very concisely in recent months to move, whereas they laboured for 13 years and oversaw a situation where the workers in this vitally important industry are at risk of losing their jobs. Employment Committee

Speaker: Mr ZAMMIT
Title: NOES
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is it true that the situation in eastern Zaire represents a serious threat to the well-being of up to a million people and to the peace and security of central Africa? What is the government's response to the developing humanitarian crisis in eastern Zaire and what steps has it taken to contribute to the alleviation of the suffering there?

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: NOES
text: I thank the honourable member for Lowe for his question and recognise his deep interest in these sorts of humanitarian issues. The government is indeed deeply troubled by the humanitarian disaster unfolding in eastern Zaire. Between 700,000 and one million people are on the move in eastern Zaire, made up of both refugees and Zaireans. The people of the Great Lakes region have suffered enough over recent years. We urge all parties to the conflict to exercise restraint and to demonstrate respect for the dignity and common humanity of all those people caught up in the fighting. The government is monitoring the situation in eastern Zaire very closely. We are in contact with the United Nations and NGO partners active in the region in order to gain the most complete picture of the situation on the ground. We are pleased to note that Australian NGOs are moving quickly to raise funds for the alleviation of the suffering of those affected by the fighting. In this way NGOs will be able rapidly to assist once the situation becomes clearer and it is possible to reach people who are affected by the crisis. The government will consider contributing to emergency appeals launched by Australian NGOs. Contributions will be determined on the basis of rapid response assistance proposals. This mechanism allows the government to provide a rapid response to emergencies while maintaining an appropriate level of accountability for taxpayers' money. A simple standard format is available to NGOs for submission of such proposals. The government believes that international initiatives to resolve the crisis in Zaire should focus primarily on developing a comprehensive approach, including confidence building measures in both Rwanda and Burundi designed to support the early, voluntary and the safe return of the refugees. Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism

text: I thank the member for Menzies for his question. I can give that categorical assurance sought by the member. In fact, I refer particularly to an article in the Australian today which relates the circumstances of a second-year apprentice carpenter. The fact of the matter is that this carpenter, and others like this person referred to in the paper this morning, will not have their wages cut by our bill. I appreciate there is a scare campaign being run by the opposition on this issue, despite the fact that we have given the shadow minister for industrial relations an extensive briefing on exactly what the proposal is. Despite a clear statement of the factual circumstances that face these people, we are still getting a campaign run by the opposition to basically scare young people about the implications of our bill when they know very well the provisions of our bill will give young people the opportunity for apprenticeships and traineeships which they have been denied by the Labor Party for years and years and years. I think they ought to think long and hard about running a scare campaign which is aimed at undermining a very sensible reform, the principles of which have in fact, when Labor was in government, been supported by the previous Labor government. Mr Speaker, let me put the matters, hopefully for the last time for the shadow minister, once again on the public record so it is very clear. Where there is an award rate of pay established for the particular traineeship, including a national training wage trainees hip or an apprenticeship, then that rate will continue to apply whether the person is employed under an award or under a workplace agreement. In other words, there is no change-n-o c-h-a-n-g-e-no change. The only area where there is some change is for new traineeships and apprenticeships where currently there is no relevant trainee award rate of pay. That will generally occur because you get a change in the mix of hours between training and work. Opposition member interjecting

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: NOES
text: We get the interjectionsurprise and concern. But where there is a different mix, you yourselves acknowledge the principles by which we have defined this scheme-not just the previous Labor government but also the Industrial Relations Commission and the ACTU. It is an absolute disgrace that you should walk away from a principle which underpinned a sensible scheme to help young people into traineeships and apprenticeships. This is an excellent scheme. I am surprised that you continue to run a scare campaign. I was very pleased that in the discussions with the Australian Democrats we went over all these issues. They raised the very scare campaign that you have been running, and we were able ta"show them in absolute detailwith dotting the i' s and crossing the 1's-the benefits for young people under this scheme. Therefore, I was pleased that on the weekend we were able to announce that the scheme will proceed. Furthermore, in those discussions-and I want to pay tribute to my colleague, the minister responsible for training, who also had negotiations with the Democrats-we made a number of changes to the scheme to improve it even further. So the scheme will proceed. This statement and set of circumstances in the Australian are absolutely wrong. I would hope that the opposition will change their view on it. Film: 1956 Olympic Games

Speaker: Mrs SULLIVAN
Title: NOES
text: My question is adOlympic dressed to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government. Is the minister aware that historically significant and extensive original film footage of the 1956 Olympic Games in Melbourne is about to be removed from Australia to the custody of an American company, The Big Fight Inc., and will, are therefore, be lost to Australia forever? Is minister able to indicate what action he able to take to protect this historically and culturally significant film?

Speaker: Mr WARWICK SMITH
Title: NOES
text: I thank the not member for her question. I would like to inform the parliament of events that took place this morning. In my capacity as Acting is Minister for Communications and the Arts, I have taken action to retain in Australia the original film footage of the 1956 Melbourne Olympic Games. A dispute over the ownership of this original footage of the 1956 Olympics, which was shot by a film maker called Peter Whitchurch, went to the Federal Court late last week. The Federal Court has found in favour of an American company called The Big Fight Inc. In anticipation of this company wishing to take the original material out of Australia, this morning the Governor General, at a special meeting of the Executive Council, signed an amendment to the regulations of the Protecof Movable Cultural Heritage Act, giving the Minister for Communications and the Arts power to prevent the export of the materiThe regulations of the act include the is national cultural heritage control list, which prescribes what is protected by the act. But, this includes films that are over 75 years of age, which does not cover the 1956 Olympics. Today's amendments to the regulainclude original documents relating to an the 1956 Melbourne Olympic Games specifically and on the list means that these items it cannot be exported without a permit being by the Minister for Communications I also found in inquiring into this matter that Film Australia declined to film the 1956 Games and that the National Film and Sound Archive does not hold the negatives of the extensive footage. I do not think anyone would dispute the significance of this film footage or, indeed, any original documents relating to the 1956 Olympics. They had an enormous impact on Melbourne and important for all of Australia. To lose that the original footage and the capacity to obtain is and retain that original footage would be a tragedy. Therefore, the government has acted the way that it did this morning.
