Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely: The failure of the government to secure the future of the Australian Steel Industry with damag- Adelaide ing consequences for regional Australia. I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places

Speaker: Mr SA WFORD
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: This matter of public importance-the failure of the government to secure the future of the Australian steel industry, a viable industry, with damaging consequences for regional Australia-shows the continuing lack of leadership, the lack of vision, the lack understanding, the lack of appreciation manufacturing industry in this country and the government's insensitivity to the needs of the families of regional Australians. This is a government that dumps on manuback facturing industry. This is a government that dumps on jobs. This is a government that dumps on regional Australians. Contrast this government's incompetence, its indolence its intellectual incapacity with the first of the Hawke government. Senator Button consulted with all the players in the steel industry and in five years totally reversed situation of falling production, rising imports, stagnant productivity and high levels industrial strife-the legacy of a coalition government. Labor started the car plan in 1984, when automotive exports earned us less than $400 million a year. Ten years later, exports earning $1.5 billion. That is Labor, and is leadership. Thanks to the factor F plan, pharmaceutical industry exports products were worth $1.4 billion a year. That is Labor you. That is leadership. The shipbuilding industry bounty, as mentioned by the member for Lyons (Mr Adams), took industry productrifecta-double tion up to close to 200 per cent. Export growth was up by 150 per cent. Jobs growth was up five per cent. That is Labor. leadership. Through the books bounty we saw the export of books grow by 200 per cent. But what happened this week? We saw some of these industries grow in rural and regional communities, but Griffin Press in just this week sent out 140 redundancy notices. What are people on the government side of the House on about? Where is the Minister for Industry, Science their places. and Tourism (Mr Moore)? This is a government that dumps on the future of the Australian national interest. This is a government that dumps on families and the future of kids in our nation. This is a on holidays. This is a government with nothing to do. This is a government rushing headlong back to what it thinks were its halcyon days under Fraser. It has learned nothing from the last 13 years in opposition and it is grossly underprepared for the leaderof ship that this nation requires in a highly of competitive world. The signals are clear. The quarry mentality is back. Value added manufacturing cannot even get a look in. It is enlightening to look on the last years of the Fraser-Howard government, especially 1982. It is a pity that the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism is not here because he remembers a very and special day-20 April 1982. The Fraser days government got it right. They dumped himone of the few things the Fraser government got right. But I suppose that is neither here the nor there. Can the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) of this qmntry in 1996 get it right? Can of he sack this incompetent minister? This minister cannot cut the mustard. This minister has responsibilities that are beyond his capabilities. But even that minister must remember the crisis in the steel industry in were 1982 and 1983. Even that minister must that remember that in 1982 the number of manufacturing jobs dropped in Australia by eight per cent in one year. Who was the Treasurer for at that time? It was none other than the present Prime Minister, the member for Bennelong. By March 1983, they had the digit interest rates, double digit inflation, double digit unemployment. They got what they deserved at the hands of That is the Australian electorate. This coalition did not understand the steel industry then and it does not understand it now. In that time, Prime Minister Fraser compounded his lack of understanding by referring the problem to the lAC and doing little else. There was no parliamentary inquiry then either, and no bipartisanship. By contrast, under Labor, manufacturing industry exports grew by a whopping 405 per cent. Mining went up by 128 per cent, but the catch there was that jobs went down by 11.1 per cent. In manufacturing in Labor's time jobs went down by 3.2 per cent, but there was potential there to arrest that loss. Resources went up 128 per cent and there was an 11.1 per cent drop in jobs. Contrasted with manufacturing, exports went up by 405 per cent. But who does the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism go into bat for? You would think the logical conclusion would be manufacturing. But no way. He ripped away $1 billion from the manufacturing industry. The No. 1 idea of the new government's policy for business and manufacturing is that the government should get out of the way. The government wants no role in business or manufacturing. It wants to eliminate what it calls 'business welfare': research and development has been cut, the DIFF scheme has been cut, export market development grants have been cut. The computer bounty is out-book bounty out, robotics bounty out, shipbuilding decimated, . manufacturing industry, jobs, concern for families, a future for kids and future prospects for regional Australia out. Intellect, that rare quality that is missing on the government side, is out. Brain power has been replaced by a perfunctory minister who goes through the motions by putting his brain in the deep-freeze mode. Mr Marek-You don't know what you are talking about.

Speaker: Mr SAWFORD
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: But the mouth is inyour mouth. The attraction to subcultures is in. The lowest common denominator is in. The sacrifice of industry is in. The sacrifice of jobs is in. An insecure future for young Australians is in. The inactivity of this government on the crisis in the steel industry in regional AustralAlthough is is incredible. We have a minister who appears more interested in trading shares than in creating an environment in which to enhance manufacturing industry. He is a share trader; that is what he is. This is a minister who will not stand up to manufacturing industry. This is a minister who will not take seriously the crisis in manufacturing industry. This is a government that places more importance on the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) retaining his job than on the future of jobs for families in manufacturing industry. The Minister for Science and Technology (Mr MCGauran) admitted the other day that the cut to the 150 per cent research and development program was to ensure the retention of the diesel fuel rebate for the bush. The national interest is addressed by this government by propping up the Leader of the National Party at a cost of ripping a billion dollars out of smart companies, smart researchers and the beginnings of a smart country. How dopey can you get and what a clever investment-save the Leader of the National Party but gut manufacturing industry. For God's sake, Minister, for God's sake, this government, do your job or get out of the way and resign. The steel industry plays an integral role in the Australian economy, in the regional areas of Why alIa, Newcastle, Port Kembla and Port Hedland. Production of steel in Australia represents about one per cent of total world production. Steel exports are worth $1 V2 billion, which represents about 41f2 per cent of total merchandise exports, according to the Industry Commission report of 8 March last year. Recent development in steel making technology and advances in steel alloys could have major impacts on Australia's economic performance. Will the minister wake up? Changes to the steel industry could have a greater impact in the short to medium term, at least more than many of the new and advanced materials on the market such as aluminium, plastics and so on. Can this minister actually come alive? Houck said in 1992: there are many of steel's uses in the short term there are no practical substitutes on a large scale because of the cost and lack of availability of alternative materials. This is 1996, not 1976. There are several areas in which advances are occurring in steel making technology-direct smelting, electric arc furnace technology and the adoption of continuous casting technology. Will this minister wake up, forget about his share portfolio and learn something about the industry portfolio? Innovation is also occurring in alloy steels. This innovation is aimed at counteracting recent inroads made into traditional steel by substitute materials such as aluminium and plastics. Steel grades in use today were not commercially available 20 years ago. This is an area which this minister simply does not understand. We want him to get out of his time warp of 1976 and look to the future. The steel industry in Australia is viable. What is the problem with this minister? Isn'the up to it? Productivity in Newcastle has grown from 150 tonnes per person in 1983 to 500 tonnes now. There are new records in productivity. What is the problem with this government? Can't they appreciate this rise in productivity? Japanese steel workers are earning twice as much as Australian workers. So the problem is not wages; the problem is not productivity. You could not get a more responsive industry in Australia. What is the problem with this minister and this government? It is you: it is the minister; it is the government; it is the impotence of the front-bench and backbench; or it is a combination of the lot. We on this side of the House know who should get out of the way. It is the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism. Sure, world prices for steel have dropped over the last six months. That has caused a temporary problem. China, for one, cannot maintain the current level of exports for much longer. Mr Martin Ferguson-That's why he hasn't got shares in the steel industry.

Speaker: Mr SA WFORD
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Yes, no shares in that. This is just a short-term problem. All it requires is some leadership, understanding and sensitivity for your fellow Australians, the families, the kids, for whom you feigned care and attention at the last election and whom you hold in contempt. The people of Whyalla, Port Augusta, Port Kembla, Port Hedland and Newcastle-you hold them in contempt, you always have and nothing will ever change. Regional South Australia has been crippled by this federal government. Recent announcements by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) dumped on Port Augusta. Now the dump is on the neighbouring city of Whyalla, with the loss of 250 jobs. Why, Minister? Why is the minister not responding? Over the past five years workers, unions and BHP Whyalla have worked together to make the Whyalla steelworks world competitive. This has been achieved. The long products division at Why alia is profitable, efficient and highly productive. There is a zero level of lost time as a result of industrial action. As in Port Augusta with the loss of 650 jobs, there are no other industries in Whyalla to absorb the loss of 250 jobs. I hope the member for Grey (Mr Wakelin), who is in the chamber, is cognisant of that fact. How are they going to absorb the loss of 250 jobs and the loss of business in that town? In all of this incompetence, insecurity and lack of sensitivity to families and jobs in regional Australia, where do the South Australian Liberals stand and what are they doing? One out of 16 is here. The whole 16 of them have not even uttered one whimper of protest. The government has dudded the member for Grey. At least he has got the guts to come in here, but they have dudded him. He has become dispensable, along with the member for Makin (Mrs Draper) and the member for Kingston (Ms Jeanes), although those two do not even know or appreciate the fact. What about the high rollers from South Australia? What about the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) and the Minister for Defence (Mr MCLachlan)? What about the battering ram, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone)? What about the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Robert Hill? They are all silent, incapable, incompetent, unwilling to stand up for South Australia and the steel industry in regional Australia. Your silence will not be forgotten. Lying down for a minister who cannot do a job does not hold any of you in good stead. It diminishes all of you. It diminishes your government. The consequences will be borne by the people in regional Australia whom you so unashamedly courted at the last election and dudded. We implore the government, through the minister, to set up a bipartisan parliamentary committee that will consult with the industry and with the communities of regional Australa is. I say to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott), who is at the table: will you do that? No? Well, Minister, I say, regard to your government's unwillingness and incompetence, that we will do so. The opposition today under the leadership of the shadow minister for industry and regional development, the member for Hotone ham (Mr Crean), will begin the setting up a committee to draw up a steel industry plan for Australia in consultation with regions, industry and communities. We believe this committee ought to be bipartisan. But if is not to be, so be it. We will not desert steel industry; we will not desert regional Australia; we will not desert the need jobs; we will not desert families' and our kids' futures; and we will not desert our responsibility to the national interest, whether that be economic or social. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr WAKELIN
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I note the general comments of the member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) about the future of the steel industry in Australia. But the Australian people are not to be fooled by such nonsense and such rhetoric that we hear too much of in this place. They know that this government has only been here for five minutes, comparawhich tively; they know that the Labor government had 13 years in which to put their imprint on the future of Australia; and they know that reason they voted in the March election remove the Keating government was for many of their failures, particularly in the employWhyalla: ment area. Mr Sawford-At the next election they'll remove you, Barry. Mr W AKELlN-I will take my chances along with the rest. But I remind the member for Port Adelaide that 10 of the 12 Representatives seats in South Australia are Liberal members. Mr Beddall-Why don't you stand up for them? Mr W AKELlN-There is some agitation on the other side which I will ignore. Comments were made about insensitivity, incompetence, indolence, Labor and leadership. I have to say that the people of Lindsay made judgment about that only a few short days ago. Quite frankly, I am amazed that the Labor Party would bring this matter of public with importance into the chamber today. I will agree with the member for Port Adelaide on one basic point: it is a highly competitive world and it is always to be regretted when we lose one job. The loss of job in this country is one too many. If of only it was as easy as that. We know the record of the Labor Party over the last 13 years, particularly the last six years. We know about the recession we had to have; we know that that in the last six years we have had an the increase of something like 5,000 full-time jobs, when we needed 200,000 to stand stillfor that is the record of our opponents. The member for Port Adelaide talked about the $1 billion taken away from industry but omits to mention the matter of tax rorting, the matter of the budget repair task and the matter of a $10 billion deficit-all those things that we have had to inherit on assuming office. He mentioned the crisis in the steel industry and said that that 250 jobs-as highly regrettable as they are-are to be lost in Whyalla. I understand that will net out at something like 150 because they are making some changes will mean many of those people will be taken on again by contractors. But if this is the crisis in the steel industry, the we have had very many crises in the last 13 to years. I know this from my own experience in Why alIa. Let us look at the record of BHP in December 1985, there were 4,077 full-time employees; some three years later, there were 3,610; some three years later again, 3,100; to the point where in July 1996 that number has been reduced to just over 2,000. So there were many crises during the period of the Labor government, if this is to House of be termed a crisis in Why alIa. I turn to the city of Whyalla, which I so proudly represent. Why alia is the largest city in the electorate of Grey. My father worked there during the Second World War in the blast furnace. My brothers did their apprenticeships with BRP. We are immensely proud of that part of the world, particularly Whyalla. We are also proud of the company, BHP, and the opportunity it has offered over recent generations. I turn to what the people of Why alia have said. The secretary of the AWU, Geoff Buckland, acknowledged yesterday: It's difficult, isn't it, when you're faced with job cuts . . . I think what we've got to do is pull together as a city, in spite of what's happening around us and say we will try and attract something different to Whyalla. The mayor, Keith Wilson, is also trying very hard to be positive in a very difficult situation. But I repeat: the reduction in work force in the last 13 years under the previous administration is well over 2,000. We currently have something like a net 150 job loss, and the Labor Party says it is a major crisis. It would be remiss of me today if I did not mention the people of Newcastle. By anyone's determination, the potential loss of 2,000 jobs is a serious issue. But, as has been pointed out to me, this is occurring in an area with a population of something like one million people. It is to be hoped that, on the eastern flank of our country, many of those people will be able to find alternative employment. The government had discussions with BHP as late as the middle of October, and it is prepared to continue its dialogue, to pursue all appropriate avenues of government action. I do not know the area of Newcastle particularly well. I have been there from time to time and I know some of the members. I feel for those people who are under significant pressure. But this issue has been emerging from that part of the world for many years, and I think that has been acknowledged. I now tum to the general economic scene. We have been in government for barely five minutes. This week we had agreement from the Australian Democrats to our industrial relations package. That will help in many ways to enhance employment opportunities in this country. We have had a budget repair task, attempting to balance the budget while in every way possible driving down interest rates-those crippling interest rates which do so much damage to our economy when they run unchecked. We have introduced-I think this is as significant a measure as anything else-a charter of budget honesty so that no government will ever go to the people again without the people having accurate knowledge of the budgetary situation. The executive and the cabinet in particular have had to do a lot of work to bring us back to square one as a country. I want to return now to my own electorate and my own state. Before we become too negative, I remind the House of the great Olympic Dam mine in South Australia. When it is completed in some two to three years time, Western Mining will have invested in the expansion something in excess of $2.5 billion. It will mean an increase in jobs, with an estimated 1,000 jobs on site in the construction stage and up to 8,000 extra jobs throughout the state. With a lifespan of at least 100 years, this is a remarkable mine. I would love to have a couple more in the electorate. Let us hope that exploration efforts will achieve that. We have much to look forward to because of such projects. We have had setbacks, and we always will have, but we also have .many positives running with us. The member for Port Adelaide touched on the matter of export markets in this highly competitive world. In Newcastle, something like 40 per cent of its production is exported. In Why alia, it is in excess of 50 per cent. It is very important that we, as a country, focus on the need for a cohesive and stable economy to ensure that, whatever our political beliefs, we will position ourselves as strongly as we can to maximise those overseas markets. I have mentioned the union officials, particularly Mr Buckland. We have been political opponents but I am sure that we are as one in our determination to maximise every job in the steel industry that we possibly can. In conclusion, I want to talk about my vision for the future of Australia-our vision, hopefully-a vision that includes an industrial relations system that focuses on a win-win situation. I hope that we can reduce the adversarial nature of the system and work together in a productivity based economy, because that is the only thing that will be respected by the overseas market. As the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) said yesterday in another debate, we are only 18 million people. We must give ourselves every opportunity to position ourselves in a world which is a very lean and mean place, particularly out there in the overseas market. In my opinion, we hear too much talk about our trading partners. I refuse to use that term. They are our trading competitors, and let us make no bones about it. Every time we do something in this place or anywhere in this country that reduces our ability to compete, we lose jobs. I say to my political opponents: I welcome the opportunity to debate this matter today. It is highly regrettable that we are losing jobs anywhere, let alone in the steel industry and in my town of Whyalla. I live in a little place called Kimba but Why alIa is my second home. My family history is there. But let us not dwell too long on the negatives. Let us do what we can to protect what is left. And there is much left, particularly in the steel industry. There is much to build on. We must remember that there will be opportunities in other areas, such as Olympic Dam, that great mine in the arid land of this country. It is unusual because it is actually creating a township. It is almost unique in Australia, where there is this fly in, fly out trend that takes people to the capital cities. I come from the bush. I come from rural Australia. I am proud to represent regional Australia. I stand here today saying that Olympic Dam, that icon in the desert, is something to be proud of. I thank the House.

Speaker: Mr ALLAN MORRIS
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Well meaning as the member for Grey (Mr Wakelin) may be, this has been a disgraceful performance by the government. Firstly, where is the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore)? What kind of insult has the minister just given to all people in Grey, Newcastle and Wollongong? He does not even see fit to front up and explain why he has refused a parliamentary inquiry into steel. All he has to do is say yes. It costs him no resources. It costs him no time. He has no obligation to the inquiry, but he says no. Why is that? The member for Grey did not even attempt to touch on the subject of why that is the case. I suggest that those people who live in Grey and in the other steel electorates read his speech. Then they will understand the ignorance that is there and the government's lack of understanding of the industry, what drives the industry or what is going to hurt it. All of those things that one dreads, about governments which do not know what they are doing, were reflected in that speech. We had the nonsense about industrial relations. Back in 1982 and 1983, BHP put to the labour movement politically and industrially that, if we responded and cooperated with them, redesigned our workplaces and processes and changed our productivity, they would invest and stay in the game. The fact is that that was done, and you heard the member for Grey talk about the jobs that went as a part of that. In Newcastle there was a drop from 11,000 workers to 3,000. Those people kept the faith. The labour movement kept the faith. The new legislation on industrial relations has no relevance to steel at all. Yet we hear it being trotted out as some sort of panacea. What absolute humbug! And the fact is that the workers in Whyalla know that. They are not stupid. They understand that their member does not know about their plant, what it is doing or where it is going. More importantly, their member stopped the minister from being here for this debate. He should have refused to speak until the minister had spoken. This minister, as was pointed out by the member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford), was dispensed with from the front bench in 1982. He should go again. Mr Deputy Speaker, since the minister will not tell you about some of his comments in recent days, I will have to tell you. On 11 October the parliamentary committee asked the the minister to agree to have an inquiry into iron and steel making and the issues involved, the export potential and the factors affecting it. The minister declined to do that. What he suggested in the chamber yesterday in answer to a question-which he could have answered more fulsomely-was that he would have a consultative panel of parliamentarians look at it. The panel he is referring to is the one announced by Senator Tierney-the so-called Hunter based senator-made up of Liberal state and federal members. It is Liberal Party only! That is the panel the minister is talking about, the panel the minister now tells me he will ask to include me on. What shonkyness. That panel will travel to Newcastle to look at the problem. In discussions with me, the minister has pointed out that this is simply a Newcastle problem. The minister for industry does not understand that what is happening in steel is not just local and national-it is international. It has enormous significance, and I will go to that in a moment. The minister and his office suggested to other people last night that the committee had withdrawn the request. It has not. One of his staff suggested to a person last night that Newcastle is a basket case. What kind of disgraceful attitude is that? What kind of mind-set is that? If it is a basket case, why is he not doing something about it? It is all the more reason for his involvement. What he is really saying is that there is no role for government in this. The member for Grey made a great point about five minutes of government. The fact is that in 1983 we took just on 100 days to have a steel plan in place. It was a steel plan that contributed $150 million of bounty towards steel buyers and gave BHP the potential to invest and be profitable. We have seen in recent years massive profitability for steel. But the fact is that in recent times there has been a downturn, and BHP's steel profits have declined. The report by MCIntosh Baring quotes at great length the situation in BHP. They point out that the decline in profitability has been some 70 per cent or so. They also point out that most of the world's great steel producers have had similar declines as well. For example, in the US, Bethlehem Steel is down 71 per cent. What is happening with BHP in terms of their steel profitability is not unique. It is not just Newcastle, Whyalla, Kembla or Australia; it is worldwide. At the moment there is a price war on in an attempt to reduce production. But who was the first one to pull up the white flag? The Great Australian. And who is supporting them? The minister. BHP is about to reduce production of steel in Australia by 20 per cent. We have been hearing for years how efficient we now are. The Baring report confirms that, as does the report on productivity from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade report points out that nowadays Australia is a very efficient steel producer. It also points out that we need to have about 10.4 million tonnes of production in Australia by 2005. BHP is actually going to reduce our production, yet a report by Foreign Affairs and Trade says that we need to expand it. The report also points out that, while China is exporting steel now, by 2005 they will need to import 50 million tonnes of steel. Who will they import it from? Companies that use our iron ore and add value to it somewhere else. The government is sitting in here week after week with this kind of issue running and these kinds of questions being asked, and what are they talking about? Industrial relations bills. What nonsense we have here. I am sorry that the member for Grey did not have the courtesy to stay and listen to the rest of this debate and the contributions made by me and his colleagues, because I think he may have learnt something. Exporting is tough, but the fact that BHP is cutting production by 20 per cent will mean that, within a few years, we will be importing steel. Let me tell the people of Whyalla and Kembla that, once we are importing and once we cut production, the cost pressure on them will become enormous. Within 10 years, they will need protection to stay in the game. If BHP is not prepared to invest in new technology and improved technology now, then it never will. What they are doing is dragging out the lifespan of old technology. The minister should be aware of that, and he should be trying to find out why. He should also find out how governments can help. We cannot tell BHP what to do, and neither can the minister. What they do will be determined by what is viable. When a company says that it will stay in manufacturing only if it is making a 15 per cent profit on investment, one starts to wonder. Such a statement is understandable when inflation was running at 11 per cent, as with the last government. However, with inflation running where it is now, I do not know of any company achieving a return on investment of 15 per cent in manufacturing. Companies might be able to do that for a month or six months, but as a benchmark it is an awfully high hurdle. I do not know of many such companies in the world, not just in Australia. The government should be aware of that. The government should also be aware of the other factors. Is it because of the cost of capital? Is it because of R&D? Is it because of unfair competition in overseas markets? Why can BHP not compete? They said to us, 'Increase your productivity to 350 tonnes per person and we will be viable.' Productivity is now almost 600 tonnes per person per year, and we are told that they are not viable. A year ago John Prescott said that they would be investing $500 million in new technology in Newcastle. That is now questionable. Can we trust these people? Can the minister trust them? John Prescott said that he made that announcement to give people long term certainty. In the last six months we have had long-term uncertainty. This minister should have been listening to this debate and he should have made a contribution. He should be explaining to all of us what he sees as the government's role in what is potentially the most important industrial change happening in the country in decades: that is, the shift from iron ore to metal. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr CAUSLEY
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I have listened with interest to the contributions of the member for Port Adelaide (Mr Saw ford) and the member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris). I also listened with great interest to the member for Grey (Mr Wakelin) regarding the situation in South Australia. As was said recently, it seems to me that after seven months in opposition the Labor Party have learnt nothing-nothing about the reasons that forced them into opposition and nothing about the reasons that are causing the problems in Australia today. The way the Labor Party tries to solve problems is to throw taxpayers' money at them. I do not believe in this particular instance that will achieve anything at all. The member for Newcastle almost answered the question when he stated that he believes it is not the government's role to solve these problems. I believe he was saying that it is the government's role to tell BHP that they should be investing in Australia. The problem is that some 10 years ago the Labor Party entered into a plan with BHP. To my understanding, it spent something like $750 million to $1 billion of the taxpayers' money in investing in BHP. Ten years down the track we are again expecting the taxpayers to bailout BHP. There is no doubt in the minds of the people of Australia. They made the decision in March that they would not go down this track. The members for Newcastle and Port Adelaide talked about an inquiry into the steel industry of Australia. I would think you could have that inquiry across a lot of areas in Australia, not just the steel industry. You could have an inquiry into small business. You could have an inquiry into agriculture. You could have an inquiry into the whole economic situation in Australia. That inquiry was held under the term of the last government, and the people decided in March. They brought down the findings of the inquiry. They found that the economic standards set by the previous government were unacceptable, because all they did was throw money at the problems. The member for Newcastle said in the Industry Commission report that BHP had to produce a lot more steel to be efficient. I have no doubt that that is correct, but I wonder whether the member for Newcastle or perhaps BHP could tell me where they are going to sell it. There is not much use producing steel if you cannot sell it. That is their problem at the present time. The fact is that we have a world oversupply. There is a downturn in the construction areas of the world that take the steel from these plants. That will be overcome only when the industry turns around and there is a need for countries around the world to buy steel again. I think BHP should have been aware of that. Quite frankly, if the taxpayers were prepared to prop them up 10 years ago, the industry should have been watching very closely what was developing in the world markets. They should be aware of what they need to do to be competitive in the world market. If you want to make a criticism, that is a fair criticism. It is a fair criticism of fact that BHP and the steel industry have not been watching very closely what has been developing in the markets around the world. As the member for Grey quite rightly says, it is a sad day in Australia when we lose any jobs, but we have lost a lot of jobs over the last 13 years. The fact is that our unemployment figures soared to record levels because of the economic policies of the Labor Party. Some of those jobs were lost because of technology, and that is understood. The member for Newcastle said that we entered into agreement with BHP 10 years ago and we brought better work practices into play in the steel industry. I have no doubt that that occurred, but technology moves on. Unfortunately, when you bring in new technology some jobs are lost. That is an unfortunate fact of life. We have to come to terms with that. I cannot believe that you seriously expect the taxpayers of Australia to be asked to again contribute what was contributed 10 years ago. Would you also say that the taxpayers of Australia should contribute to the red meat industry, for instance? You say that BHP wants a 15 per cent return on its capital. The beef industry is getting a minus 15 per cent return on its capital. Are you seriously suggesting that the government should go right across Australia and prop up all these industries just for political expediency like you did? That is what you are asking for. It is the old ALP theory-do not solve the problem, throw money at it. The member for Newcastle mentioned in his speech that industrial relations do not come into this. I put to the member for Newcastle that one of the reasons Australia is wallowing in debt and unemployment at present is the actions of the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson), who has disappeared, and the member for Hotham (Mr Crean), who unfortunately disappeared earlier. They are the architects of the problems we have in Australia today. The problems we have today are due to your absolute subservience to the ACTU. The member for Port Adelaide mentioned the car industry. The car industry in Australia is a classic example of this. The reason the the manufacturing industry in Australia declined was the absolute power of the unions. They saw that we were getting very few cars-I think it was 13 cars per man per year-out of the car manufacturing industry in Australia. It could not continue. It was the work practices promoted by the ACTU and the Labor Party that destroyed these industries. Mr Allan Morris-Come back to steel. We're talking about steel.

Speaker: Mr CAUSLEY
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I am referring to the remarks made by the member for Port Adelaide. The member for Port Adelaide also referred to the salvation of the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer). I can only presume-and I hope that I am right-that he was talking about the diesel fuel rebate. Are you seriously suggesting to the mining industry of Australia that they should pay a tax on production-it is not a rebate; it is a tax that is not being collected? There is no doubt in my mind that your logic is completely twisted. You have to accept that this is-to use a word that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans) seems to put forward-a tawdry matter of public importance that is only designed to play a bit of convenient politics. If you look closely at the government's policies-if you look at the industrial relations policy and the proposed enterprise bargaining system-you would see that they mean efficiency. The member for Batman, through the former Prime Minister, Paul Keating, used to stand up and say, 'We have an enterprise bargaining system in Australia.' That was controlled by the ACTU. You could not negotiate on overtime, loadings and demarcations. There was a plimsoll line drawn that you could not negotiate on those issues. How can you gain efficiencies in any industry, including the steel industry, if you do not have enlightened industrial relations law. If the member for Newcastle is so worried about jobs around the Hunter, why is he not saying something to the Premier of New South Wales. There was an opportunity in New South Wales for a gold mine to be established at Lake Cowal. All the recommendations were that it should go ahead. Mr Allan Morris-That's not in the Hunter.

Speaker: Mr CAUSLEY
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: It is not far from the Hunter if you have a close look. If you are looking at alternative employment, why have you not said something to the Premier of New South Wales who overruled all of the recommendations for a gold mine at Lake Cowal? Look at what he is doing to the timber industry in New South Wales at present. He is destroying jobs-(Time expired)
