Speaker: Mrs JOHNSTON
Title: CHILD CARE LEGISLATION
text: Canning) (4.15 p.m.)No doubt one of the main reasons for the massive growth in the demand for child-care places that I spoke about before the commencement of question time is the increasing number of women who return to the work force after commencing a family. A Sydney based consultancy called Families at Work has compiled national figures which show that 90 per cent of working women plan to return to work after childbirth, and that most return to work just after 12 months. When surveyed, many women said they would return up to nine weeks earlier if child care was available to them. The coalition's theme of choice, so necessary for women both at home and in the work force, is very evident in the legislation to which I speak today. Coalition policies are based on an absolute commitment to provide greater opportunities for both women and men to share both the rewards and the responsibilities of work and family life. The Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill we are debating now is a budget related bill. We should not look at it in isolation from other budget related measures, as they are all part of an integrated plan to make life easier for those Australians on low and middle incomes. Tbis government's child-care strategy, announced by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) in the August budget, will deliver equitable, flexible and high quality child care. It will ensure that families have access to affordable child care that is appropriate to their needs. The coalition will protect the current benefits to low income families and those with special needs. At the same time, we are establishing a strategic direction for the long-term sustainability of the child-care sector. As the Minister for Family Services, the honourable member for Pearce (Mrs Moylan), said in her second reading speech, the repeal of section 11 from the Child Care Act addresses the inequities in government funding between families using private long day centres and community centres. Removing the operational subsidy to the community based long day care centres will place private long day care centres on an equal footing and will also encourage greater efficiencies. The operational subsidy will continue to be made available by the federal government for family day care, occasional care, outside school hours care, multifunctional children's services and multifunctional Aboriginal children's services. All of these services are crucial to meeting the diverse child-care needs of Australian families. The quality of care will not be affected by the withdrawal of the operational subsidy for community based services, as this will be maintained for all family long day care services through the quality, improvement and accreditation system. The minister noted in her speech that at the present time there is no link between a family's income and their level of entitlement to the child-care cash rebate, and this is clearly not equitable. We will ensure that access to the child-care cash rebate will be retained for all Australian families regardless of their income level. That is what the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill is all about. It may be appropriate at this stage to remind members on the other side of a comment that was made by the National President of the Australian Federation of Child Care Centres, Mrs Evelyn Callaghan who, when asked about the budget, stated: In tenns of child care generally, I think the cuts have been done reasonably and rationally. She went on to say that its expected effects were measured and that it would impact on higher income families-thus making the system fairer. Members opposite should also remember that child-care assistance and the child-care cash rebate will be retained. As of January 1998 these will be paid through a new government delivery agency. This means a notable reduction in red tape, which will benefit both parents and providers alike. Most importantly, families will be able to choose for themselves whether they wish to receive their payments directly or have them paid to the child-care service of their choosing. In addition, this government is committed to ensuring that families with young children are given greater freedom to choose whether one parent cares full time for their children at home or whether both parents will remain in the work force. As I mentioned before, the changes we are making to child care should not be looked at in isolation. The coalition's policies are guided by a commitment to deliver responsible government. We place emphasis on maximising choice and opportunity for all, whilst maintaining a secure safety net for those Australians who find themselves in a disadvantaged situation. The coalition recognises that the various roles of women are complex and, more often than not, involve a delicate balance of juggling work and family responsibilities. We are committed to giving women more freedom of choice. Not all women want to join the work force. Some only do so out of the economic necessity for their families to survive. On the other hand, there are many, many women who wish to continue their careers full time after they have children. They find their work fulfilling and an important part of their life. Others, of course, choose to combine the two and work part time whilst looking after their children. We in the coalition want to make it easier for all women, whatever their individual situation is, to get ahead in life. To assist women in making the choices that suit them, the coalition government will facilitate workplace reforms to improve opportunities for women. I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate the Minister for Industrial Relations, Peter Reith, and the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Cheryl Kernot, for negotiating a sound and sensible industrial relations bill which will benefit women by promoting more flexible hours and permanent part-time work. I believe that the workplace reform legislation and the subsequent amendments agreed with the Democrats bring the industrial relations system up to date to deal with the needs of women in the workplace. The present industrial relations system based on the award structure evolved because it related to full-time male employees. The new package is more relevant to working women as it maintains their existing working conditions and enables them to vary their working hours. The new legislation promotes improved access to permanent part-time work with regular hours, which is precisely what women want. Many of these women will be seeking affordable child care. The government is maintaining this for families who choose to pay for child care. In addition, we have ensured that child-care assistance is equitable and goes to those families who are in greatest need. Members opposite are mischievous when they say we have slashed child care. This is just not so. Let me put on the record precisely what the government funding will be in the child-care sector over the next four years. Some $526 million will be spent to retain operational subsidies for family day care, occasional care, outside school hours care, multifunctional services and multifunctional Aboriginal children's services. We will spend a further $31 million to support children with high levels of additional needs, particularly those with disabilities. We have allocated $12.5 million to ensure that families in severely disadvantaged areas do not lose access to child care. We will also spend almost $11 million to provide capital funding for new places under the targeted new growth strategy to ensure that families in rural and remote areas and places of special need have access to flexible child care. Those who decry the loss of the operational subsidy to community based child-care centres should also remember that we have allocated an additional $8.3 million to assist these people to overcome the loss of this subsidy. These funds will assist centres to purchase financial or management advice to restructure their businesses should they so choose. The removal of the operational subsidy from the community based child-care centres redresses the imbalance in government subsidies and removes a significant inequity for families who are using the private child-care sector. It places the community and private long day care centres on an equal footing. After the budget was brought down, I had a number of people contact me expressing their concern about the removal of the operational subsidy. They were under the impression that the removal of the subsidy would lead to an increase in fees and a reduction in services. I have had several meetings with both parents and operators to discuss the rationale behind the decision. I outlined to them that it would be regrettable for them to immediately increase their fees or reduce their services without first analysing how they may be able to meet the proposed changes. Although many of them admitted to me that they half expected the decision that was made, they acknowledged that the government is providing the additional $8.3 million to help them come to terms with the loss of the operational subsidy. As I have already mentioned, this is in addition to the $11.5 million over three years which is available to assist centres to upgrade and amalgamate in order to improve their efficiency and viability. When the announcement was made to remove the operational subsidy, the community sector claimed to be outraged. However, a few days later the convenor of the National Association of Community Based Children's Services, Mrs Lyne Wannan, was calling on the sector to prove its viability. Commercial child-care operators, who often charge lower fees than those of the community based centres, have welcomed the removal of the subsidy as they rightly believe this will create a level playing field for all child-care centres. There are those on the opposite side of this House who have made a point today of criticising the government for its decision to remove the operational subsidy. They need to be reminded, however, that it was the Labor Party, when it was in government, that wanted to abolish the operational subsidy. Let me quote from a recent article by Peter Walsh, a former Labor senator who was probably just a little too honest for the ALP's liking. In an article entitled 'Care for the rich kids' in the Australian Financial Review of 27 August 1996, Mr Walsh said: Several times in the 1980' s Labor's expenditure review committee considered abolishing the $15 per day per place operating subsidy paid to 'community based' child care centres. The proposal had both financial and efficiency objectives: to save money, and remove the government funded bias which discriminated in favour of the country's most inefficient sector. He goes on to say, among other things, that the abolition of the subsidy will not affect charges to parents using such centres. I refer to Mr Walsh's comments to demonstrate that this is not a new idea dreamt up by the coalition in pursuit of some ideological pursuit. Indeed, the Labor Party themselves considered the very same proposal, but they never had the guts to implement it. To conclude, let me go back to the beginning of my speech and remind members that never before have so many very young children spent so much time being cared for by non-family members. It is a phenomenonsome would argue a frightening one-which is linked directly to the new high participation of women in the work force. In recognition of this, the government has put in place an economic framework broad enough to accommodate many more changes if the public and child-care industry deem them necessary. Our national planning framework, which has been set up to guide child care in this country and which has been welcomed by the centre operators as well as other child-care professionals, is one that is to be commended. This is all part of the consultative theme of this coalition government. We are listening to the Australian people, we are hearing their requests, and we are trying to be fair. I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr FITZGIBBON
Title: CHILD CARE LEGISLATION
text: I congratulate the member for Canning (Mrs Johnston) for at least being brave enough to come into the House and defend what really is the indefensible. I have to say she has done so in stark contrast to most of her colleagues on that side. I notice that we have something like six government members speaking to the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill, and I also note that the member for Canning is the only female member among them. I notice that the member for Bowman (Mrs West) was on the speaking list, but she appears to have dropped off. No doubt the member for Canning must have been grappling with two important principles: one, that she should come in here as a member of the government and defend government decisions no matter how appalling they may be, and the other of course is the principle to stay out of here and not come in here to defend what I said really is the indefensible. As she said, the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill seeks to abolish operational subsidies for community based long day care centres and to apply a means test to the former Labor government's childcare cash rebate. I am opposed to the bill and the measures it proposes. In speaking to the bill I particularly talk about its impact on rural and regional Australia. The decision to abolish operational subsidies for community based long day care centres has created more anger in my electorate than any of the other nasty decisions taken in the 1996-97 budget. That is a pretty big statement when you consider the very large range of nasties that were announced by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) in the budget. But it is true. It is true that I have received more petitions, more phone calls, more letters and attended more meetings and rallies regarding the decision to abolish the operational subsidies for child-care centres than I have on any other issue-more than I have received regarding increases in the higher education contribution charge and the cuts to universities; more than I have received regarding the changes to Austudy; more than I have received on cuts to labour market programs; more than on the proposed closure of Commonwealth Employment Service offices; more than on the closure of Medicare offices; more than on the increases to the co-payment for pharmaceuticals for both concession cardholders and non-concession cardholders; more than on the decision to deem the first $2,000 of pension savings; more representations than on the decision to remove the exemption on superannuation assets for the purpose of assessing social security entitlements; more than on the massive slashing of public sector jobs; and more than on the decision to withhold the 1 November Medicare fee increases. I have received more representations on operational subsidies than I have on the decision to cut funding for public hospitals; more than on the decision to cut the Commonwealth dental program; more than on the decision to whack more than 200,000 older Australians with a $6.80 charge for home and community care services; more than on the decision to impose a nursing home entry fee; more than on the decision to slash funding for public housing; more than on the decision to flog off Telstra; more than on the decision to cut ABC funding; and just moreonly just more-than on the decision to slash want to funding to our skillshare operations. Some of these issues came pretty close, as you can imagine, Mr Deputy Speaker. The electorate is very angry about so many of them. But, as I said, the electorate is more angry about the cuts in operational subsidies than it is regarding any other issue. I want to share with the House an example of the extent of that anger. Singleton Shire Council is a very progressive council. It is almost entirely devoid of party politics; indeed, I do not think I would be offending Singleton shire councillors if I was to say they really are a fairly conservative lot. Its members do not grandstand in order to score petty political points, and Singleton councillors enjoy a high level of community respect. In particular, the local mayor, Neil MCNamara, is held in very high regard by the citizens of the area-not only his immediate area, but within the Hunter Valley generally. Neil is also the chairman of the Hunter Region Organisation of Councils. His astute leadership and apolitical approach to issues at all levels of government have delivered him a 22-year unbroken run as leader of the Singleton and Patricks Plains shires. I share this information with honourable members to establish the apolitical bona fides of the council and its mayor. Having done that, I want to read parts of a letter I received from Mayor Neil MCNamara which he recently sent to the government. It says: At its last meeting Council expressed the gravest concern and disapproval of the severity of the proposed funding cuts outlined in almost every area of the Federal budget. It is recognised and well understood by the Councillors of the Shire that it is necessary for every individual, every organisation, every community and indeed, for the country to live within its means. However, the reality is that the country is its people, and the first consideration in any process to srutinize and amend or change existing practices and services, must be to ensure that proper regard is given to the interests of the people who will be affected by those amendments or change. Council believes that the savage cuts in expenditure in many areas affecting country people, the closure of welfare agencies and offices in country areas and the reductions in employment services have no regard whatever for the communities they affect. Whilst these expenditure cuts may have achieved a particular budget outcome for the Government, they have seriously and unrealistically affected the people the government needs to support. Everyone in the community is aware that many areas of government spending require to be rationalised but Council believes it is a matter of attacking appropriate areas having regard to needs, rather than attacking every area to achieve a pre-determined budget result. He went on to say: Of particular concern to Council is the area of childcare funding which was the subject of an earlier resolution of Council and a letter to appropriate politicians. I am sure you are aware of the demography of Singleton as it relates to mining and industry and the fact that we have an increasing young family population. As a result of this there are particular problems faced by young people with particular needs in the area of childcare facilities. You will notice, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the mayor talks about the impact of the budget on country people. It is this issue which I want to tum to. The 1996-97 budget is full of examples of funding cuts which fall disproportionately upon rural and regional Australia--cuts to skillshare and labour market programs, the closure of CES offices, cuts to the ABC and many more. But there is no better example than the decision to abolish operational subsidies for community based long day care centres, nor could there be a better example of a decision made by city based bureaucrats and politicians who have no appreciation whatsoever of its impact on rural and regional Australia. The government says that it is removing the operational subsidy to place community based centres on an equal footing with privately run centres. But you have to understand that the private sector does not involve itself in the provision of child care in country Australia because there simply is no money in it; there is no profit motive. Indeed, community providers, even with their operational subsidies, struggle to remain viable. One of their challenges is to maintain the critical mass of children needed to keep their centres open, to keep them viable. As the centres will no doubt be forced to pass on their increased running costs as a result of the abolition of the subsidy, they will have no choice but to do so and parents will be forced to withdraw their children from the centres. The result of that is that the centres in rural Australia, centres in towns in my electorate, will lose the critical mass necessary to remain viable and, consequently, will have to close their doors. What happens then? It means that women, traditionally the primary carers, will be forced to leave the work force or, alternatively, to seek out an unregistered and unaccredited backyard carer. While I suspect that the majority of unregistered carers are competent, sincere and loving of the children that they care for, let us take a look at how badly it can all go wrong. Let me read to the House part of an article which appeared in Tuesday's Maitland Mercury. The headline reads 'Abuse case Ita real minefield'''. It says: A 59-year-old woman who runs an unregistered child care service from her home has pleaded not guilty to a child abuse charge. The woman, who cannot be named to protect the alleged victim, appeared in Maitland Local Court yesterday to apply for variation on her bail conditions. Police will allege the woman abused a 2Y2-yearold boy in her care on October 17 by ill-treating and assaulting him. The charges were laid after the Department of Community Services and police intervened when a neighbour complained about the carer's treatment of the child. The solicitor said the police allegation can be summed up in this way: "That the child carer vigorously struck, swore raised her voice and yelled at the child." He told the court that parents of other children in the accused's care support the woman and want their children to stay with her. He produced a number of letters of support from the parents. But the magistrate hearing the case commented that this area of concern is a real minefield. Let me remind honourable members of an article that appeared in yesterday's Daily Telegraph. The headline read 'Don't go, mum'. It reads: A child begged not to be left with the family babysitter on the day she was murdered, the girl's mother told the court yesterday. Kym Lawson said her 18-month-old daughter had cried, "Mummy no, mummy no"as she was left with her baby-sitter. These are very graphic examples of what can go wrong. As I said, I agree and hope that in the majority of cases it does not go so badly wrong. But can we afford to take the risk? Can we afford to deny our children the education they receive when attending registered day care centres? Can we afford to deny them the camaraderie, the interaction with other children that they enjoy by attending registered day care services? For those who doubt my suggestion that some community based centres will be forced to close, let us go through some of the facts. This measure will save the government some $118 million over the next three years. To put it more succinctly, that is a loss of $33,000 each year for the Muswellbrook multicare child-care centre, $42,000 for the Singleton child-care centre, $40,000 for the Cessnock multipurpose child-care centre, $54,000 for the Beresfield community child-care centre and $40,000 a year for the Kurri centre. In the case of Muswellbrook, that is a 9.4 per cent decrease in its operating budget; Singleton, 11.5 per cent; Cessnock, 9.3 per cent; and Beresfield, a whopping 12 per cent. There can be no doubt that the centres will have no choice but to pass the losses on to their users. Indeed, some child-care centres in my electorate have already been doing the calculations. The Singleton child-care centre, which services some 120 families, estimates that it will be forced to increase its charges by $3.85 per day, or nearly $20 per week. The Beresfield community child-care centre, which also services about 120 families, estimates that its charges will increase by $5 per day, or $25 per week. It is worth noting that a very high percentage of the families that use both of these centres are receiving some sort of family allowance. That tells us that the decision to abolish the operational subsidy will hit those families with the least ability to pay-those families on low incomes. The Australian Financial Review has estimated that a family with only one child could be up to $50 worse off per week. Where does this leave Australian women? What about their basic right to go out and work? It leaves them back in the family home once again playing the traditional role of the primary family carer. This must be the government's only employment strategy: to take women out of the work force and to replace them with unemployed men. The government says it is going to allocate some $8.3 million over the next four years to assist community based long day care centres make the adjustment. Let us do some basic arithmetic. The government is going to take from the centres $118 million over three years and give them back $8.3 million over four years. So it is taking $40 million each year and giving back just $2 million. This is the compensation the member for Canning was referring to that is going to do such wonderful things for community based child-care centres. The 1, llO centres which are to share in the $8.3 million are supposed to spend the money on consultants, who are going to tell them how to run their businesses with more than lO per cent less money than they have done hitherto. When trying to justify the abolition of the operational subsidy, government members tum to the findings of the Economic Planning Advisory Council interim report. While it is true that EPAC has recommended the abolition of the subsidy, it is also true that it recommended that the money be returned to families in the form of a total child-care benefit. So the government is selectively adopting its recommendations. It is making the $118 million grab on the proposition of the report, but it is not going to give any of it back. What a disgrace! In the short time left to me I want to very briefly talk about the bill's other main proposal; that is, the proposal to means test the former Labor government's child-care cash rebate-another grab from the pockets of working Australian families. The child-care cash rebate represents a recognition that child care is a legitimate work related cost. There is no doubt about that. It is a more effective recognition than a tax deduction because tax deductibility would deliver very little relief to low income families, but would deliver a huge windfall to high income earners. I do not hear the government saying that those earning more than $70,000 a year should not be able to claim for tools of trade or for dry cleaning of uniforms. There was no logic in the decision to means test the child-care cash rebate. This proposal once again represents just another cash grab. The shadow minister has put a number of amendments to this bill before the House. I commend them to the House.

Speaker: Mr COBB
Title: CHILD CARE LEGISLATION
text: The debate from the opposition so far on this Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill has been full of misinterpretation, a combination of scare tactics and a lack of understanding of business principles. We are debating the changes to child care announced in the budget. I would like to state why these changes were necessary in a budgetary context, if I may spend a couple of minutes on that. Nobody likes making cuts in any area. As a politician, it does not necessarily make you popular. But there was a necessity for this. When .we came to power on 2 March-the same as when Richard Court came to power in Western Australia; Dean Brown, in South Australia; Jeff Kennett, in Victoria; and even Nick Greiner, back in 1988-we found a financial mess. We had a budget deficit of $10.3 billion-and that does not even factor in the Australian National debt of $1 billionand a current account deficit of $20 billion, following on the previous year, the worse current account deficit in the whole Western world. We have an overseas debt today of $188 billion, up from $23 billion when the previous government took power. Interest rates in real terms are at least one of the highest of the OECD countries, whereas home interest rates were only one per cent or two per cent in real terms in 1983 when we left power. On top of that, the unemployment rate was stuck between eight per cent and nine per cent, after going over 11 per cent when the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) was the unemployment minister. It is not a good situation to be in. Either you do nothing, let things drift on as they are and send the bill to your children and grandchildren or you do something about it, as we did across a number of portfolios, including this portfolio. That was the choice: we allow things to drift on as they are, getting worse, and bequeath the debt to our children or we wind back expenditure in a moderate, equitable and responsible manner-exactly as the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) has done to her credit with the changes she has proposed. All she has done is discontinue the operational subsidy to community long day care from 1 July next year. It is still some time away yet. Presently it is being paid at the rate of $22.60 a week for children aged between nought and three years and at $15.10 for those between three and five years old-an average of about $20 a week. On top of that, we are making other small changes. We are reducing the child-care cash rebate from 30 per cent to 20 per cent for families earning in excess of $70,000 with one child and increasing the threshold by $3,000 for each additional child. It is interesting to look at the history of the operational subsidy. It was a coalition government, after all, that brought it in back in 1972, when Bill MCMahon was Prime Minister, in the Child Care Act of 1972. We funded child care then in recognition of the increase in labour force participation by women. That was a proud coalition achievement. We provided both capital funding and recurrent funding. Over a period of time the operational subsidy, as it has come to be called, was extended not just to community long day care but to family day care, to occasional child care, to outside school hours care, to multifunction services, to multifunction Aboriginal children's services and so on. Over the next four years we will be continuing the operational subsidy to all of those except for the community long day care section. Over the next four years that will us $526 million alone-not an inconsiderable amount of money. We are not removing it from family day care, for example, which takes up a lot of places. It has been removed from community long day care only to put it on exactly the same equitable footing as the private long day care bodies which now provide most of the places. Community long day care only provides 20 per cent of the places-45,600 places right across Australia. These are the non-profit bodies, such as community organisations, local government run bodies and religious or charitable bodies which are open at least eight hours a day, Monday to Friday, for at least 48 weeks of the year providing long day care. It is interesting listening to the debate from the opposition. They always overlook the fact that in November 1985, not that long after they last obtained power, they actually reduced the operational subsidy by 50 per cent, in effect. That is something they might dwell on as they criticise the government for the necessary budget changes that we have just announced. Let us look at the figures for child-care centres. In New South Wales, my own state, there are 394 community long day care centres. Privately there are 1,112. So already the private sector, providing virtually exactly the same facility, is outnumbering them considerably. Australia-wide there are 1,102 community long day care centres providing 45,600 places. Privately there are 2,748 centres providing 122,000 places-2Y2 times more centres. Despite this subsidy of approximately $20 per child per week, the community long day care centres are charging on average $142.50, as opposed to $146.50 for the private long dare care facilities-only $4 less. The withdrawal of this operational subsidy will not only put both the private and the community long day care centres on a similar footing but in the first year it will save the government $44.7 million. We are putting in place a number of compensation mechanisms so that community long day care centres will not be disadvancost taged. Firstly, $8.3 million will be made available for financial and management advice. From 19 October advertisements have gone out calling for businesses and people to come forward to be vetted for a list that will be drawn up for each state and forwarded to each community long day care centre. They can choose whoever they want from that list to spend that money on. If you divide the 1,112 centres into $8.3 million, you come up with an average of $7,500. Most of those centres will probably only need to utilise $2,000 or $3,000 or something of that order to get that advice and get their affairs in shape. The people who work in these centres-very dedicated people whom we have all supported-have expertise in looking after children. Their expertise is not necessarily with financial matters, building or construction matters or things like that. I think they will welcome this generous grant from the minister so that they can improve their operation. On top of this, there is a further .grant of $11.5 million over the next three years to assist in upgrading these centres-as a result, no doubt, of the financial management they will receive. That will run into, on average, probably $10,000 per centre. There is another $10.9 million particularly directed towards rural centres for innovative services. I would imagine that centres that do not have any long day care available now may wish to convert rooms in a building into child-care places and that money will assist them in that. That is very welcome indeed. I thank the minister for that. There is also $12.5 million to be provided for disadvantaged areas, particularly rural and remote areas where there is no other service, so that these centres are not disadvantaged by these cutbacks. They will receive-if they can demonstrate genuine need-up to 60 per cent of the present operational subsidy. So there again we have targeted assistance to those who specifically need it. If that is not enough, on top of that we are going to provide another $31 million for children with additional needs or children with a disability. That will be available to both community and private long day care centres. It will be very welcome money indeed. I think the minister has been incredibly generous in this area. From the Treasury we have the family tax initiative, which is costing $1,000 million, I think-the member for Dawson (Mrs DeAnne Kelly) nods in agreement-in the first year. That will flow through to families with children. Depending on the number of children you have, the income you have and the age of the children, you can get anything from $7.70 up to $50 a fortnight. That has been very well accepted in the community. Let us not forget that we are spending $5,600 million on child care over the next four years. I am told that our spending next year, compared with last year under the previous government, will increase by 15 per cent. Despite these cutbacks that I have been talking about, we will be spending 15 per cent more-in fact, another $150 million-right across all those groups I have mentioned, including $526 million for the operational subsidy which will continue for most of those other groups. At this stage I would like to be a little parochial and mention both the community and private child-care centres in my electorate, all of which are of a very high standard. The community based ones are: the Bourke and District Multipurpose Child Care Centre, with 40 places in Bourke; the Brewarrina Child Care Centre, with 18 places in Brewarrina; the Little Darlings Child Care Centre in Wilcannia, which has 25 places, has only recently been opened and is very badly needed in that town; the Parkes Multipurpose Centre Long Day Care Centre, with 25 places in Parkes; the Playmates Cottage Child Care Centre, with 41 places in Dubbo; and the Rainbow Cottage Child Care Centre, with 41 places and which is also in Dubbo. I have supported many of those over the years and I will continue to work with them and do so. We also have these private centres: the Cheeky Cherubs Child Care Centre, with 70 places, has just been opened in Parkes-and I will return to that one later-the Goode Street Child Care Centre, with 44 places in Dubbo; the Noah's Ark Day Care Centre, with 39 places in Dubbo; the Orana Heights Preschool Kindergarten, with 59 places in Dubbo; and the Peppercorn Child Care Centre, with 66 places in Dubbo. That gives you some idea of the spread of both community and private long day care centres in my electorate. There are 164 places for children in community based long day care centres as opposed to 142 in private centres. That has increased recently. Family day care takes up more places: 703; multifunction places total 40; occasional care places total 17; and outside school hours care places total 145-which represents a total figure of over 1,200 places. We could do with a few more and we are getting a few more in my electorate. It is indeed instructive and interesting to look at those figures. It is also interesting to note that community long day care places have traditionally been established in areas of high need rather than in areas of low socio-economic need. That is reflected in the figures, which show that community long day care centres have a high proportion of high income families on their books. For example, only 39 per cent of their families receive the maximum child-care assistance grant whereas in the private centres 44 per cent receive the maximum grant. If you look at it in the broader context, 74 per cent of the community long day care centre families receive some child-care assistance whereas in the private centres 78 per cent receive some assistance. It is true that the community based centres have more places for babies than the private operators but, as I said earlier, they receive $7 a week more for those children and the places for babies are rapidly increasing in the private centres. In the not too distant future they will probably overtake the community centres. It is interesting that in New South Wales, in the bottom 20 per cent of socio-economic areas, private operators provide 8,700 places compared with 4,900 places in the community area. So the private operators are not necessarily picking the eyes out of the long day care places, as some have implied in the debate. They are more than pulling their weight, according to these figures. It is interesting to look at those figures in some detail. Accreditation is now compulsory for long day care centres so that both the private operators and the community operators have to be on an equal footing at least in that regard. This government, I am pleased to say, is continuing to extend that accreditation on a compulsory basis to other types of day care, such as family day care and outside school hours care. I think those on both sides of the chamber would support that. I am disappointed with the opposition's tactic of scaring parents by saying that fees will rise by gross amounts. The average subsidy for an operational grant is only about $20 per child per week, yet those opposite are talking about fees going up by $25 to $50. Having regard to all of these compensatory grants in place and the restructuring, I woulq think that in many cases fees would hardly have to rise, if at all. Those opposite also talk about centres closing. The odd centre has always closed from time to time, and I guess that will continue to occur, but I would be prepared to put $10 on the table that we will see many, many more centres open over the next year and the years ahead rather than close. I think there is provision for in excess of 45,000 more places over the next year or so. Those opposite have also talked about the EPAC report. They initiated the report. When we brought down the recommendations announced in the budget, we had not had time to fully study that report. But the EPAC report went along with many of the initiatives that we have taken. In the short time remaining to me, I would like to compare a private centre with a community centre. There is a centre in one of my towns-I will not name it-which has 40 places and was built at a cost of $350,000. This is a family small business operation. The lady who owns the centre borrowed virtually all the money for that centre. She was very fortunate in getting it at nine per cent, but that immediately is an outlay of $30,000 a year. On top of that, until 1 July next year she will not get the operational grant of $30,000 that she would have got if her centre had been a community long day care centre. So she starts $60,000 behind the eight ball, competing with the community centre up the road. I cast no aspersion whatsoever on the community centre. The community centre does a wonderful job. I have supported it and will continue to do so. She starts $60,000 behind for 40 places-not a lot of places-yet I understand she charges per child $1 per week less. She is providing almost exactly the same service, even though she starts $60,000 behind. I mentioned earlier the Cheeky Cherubs centre that has just opened down in Parkes with 70 places-I opened it myself only a month ago. Again, it is a husband and wife family business. I am delighted to say that they are going to open another one, God willing, in Forbes next year where it is desperately needed. I was astounded at the design of the building as well as the magnificent facilities and appointments within this building. It is an incredible building costing-and I hope I do not embarrass them by saying this-$470,000 of which they borrowed a fair whack of that; yet they will charge exactly the same charge, if not $1 a week less, as the community centre up the road. The service they provide to the children will be virtually exactly the same. It gives you food for thought how they can start off so far behind but still provide the same service and charge the same amount. As I say, that is not necessarily a reflection on the community centres, many of which had to struggle under voluntary labour. I have attended meetings of these people and supported them. But there is often a better way of doing things with help, and that help is forthcoming. In conclusion, I think the withdrawal of the operational grant is very reasonable indeed. The minister has done a very good job in that area. By treating it in the way she has, we will end up with a better and even larger system for long day care places. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mrs CROSIO
Title: CHILD CARE LEGISLATION
text: In June last year, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), the then Leader of the Opposition, had this to say about the importance of child care during an address to the Coalition Women's Forum: We have long accepted in the Coalition that the provision of adequate, affordable, available child care facilities ought to be part and parcel armoury of facilities and policies that are available for both men and women in Australian society the 1990s. So why do we find ourselves here in the House a year later, debating a bill sponsored by the same man which will deal such a and severe blow to the child-care industry in this country and which will now take child care out of the hands of so many Australians? Well, as with most things now involving the Prime Minister, what he says, what he really means and what he does are now all comchild-care pletely different things. However, the Howard government's attitude to child care is even better illustrated taking a look at a letter sent by the member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp )-when in his previous incarnation as the shadow minister for employment, training and family services-to Ms Pam Cahir, the National Director of the Australian Early Childhood Association. That letter is dated 28 February 1996-two days before the last federal election. I will not bore the House with all the dross at the beginning of that letter. Let me skip straight to where the good stuff is. Writing about then child-care policy, the member for Goldstein muses: The policy also states our continuing support for the community-based long day care sector, and regard the operational subsidy as one of the supports of that sector. The Coalitionwhich is now the government in this placehas no plans whatever to change the operational subsidy. I thank the member for Goldstein for putting it in writing. And yet, here we are eight months later, debating in this House the injustices of anyone. scrapping the operational subsidies for community based child care, among other things, and debating the very thing that the member for Goldstein-one of the senior members the Howard government-said would never happen if they came into government. The lesson is: they do not care. The members of the government do not care if they say one thing and do another. I am not surprised by this flagrant breach of the coalition's election commitments, although of the I am very disappointed. I am disappointed in because, despite this government's obvious aversion to it, the member for Goldstein's words do contain one basic truth-the operational subsidy is one of the key supports of the community based long day care sector, thus child care in this country. If it is to be abolished, as the Prime Minister and his Minister for Family Services, the member for Pearce (Mrs Moylan), now seem to determined to do, they will be taking away one of the very foundations of the community based system. They will be dealing a blow to the entire system of child care in this country-the equity of the system and the by availability of child care. Do not take my word for it; ask the member for Goldstein. The retention of operational subsidies for community based child care is essential for the continued quality and maintenance of the entire child-care industry. Without the subsidies the whole balance of the system is skewwhiffed. That is why I want to focus on the operational subsidies in this speech. It is via the subsidies that we were able to maintain and supply quality and affordable child care the coalition's in this country. The high hypocrisy of the whole situation is that we now have the Minister for Family we Services running hither and thither all over key the country defending this outrageous policy as if it were the central part of the coalition's child-care platform prior to the election. The minister is defending what will bring a crisis in child care in this country as if it were a well-planned and cleverly constructed measure to restore equity between private and community based long day care centres. She need not bother because she is not fooling The Child Care Act may have been introduced by the coalition government in 1970and that is where I correct the previous of speaker, the member for Parkes (Mr Cobb); even then it was with reluctance and with much reservation-but it was Labor that truly developed child care in this country. It was Labor that recognised the potential of child care for promoting and overcoming some of the social and economic inequalities that then existed and, to some extent, still do in our society. For the last eight months we have heard government members go on and on about the last 13 years under Labor. They have tried to characterise that time as a time of inaction and indulgence. In that case, it must have been the little green fairies at the bottom of the garden who increased the child-care places in this country from 46,000 in 1983 to almost 300,000 places now. It must have been Elvis Presley, when he was not working part time at a 7-Eleven store, who put together a childcare network which caters for more than 440,000 families in Commonwealth funded child care in anyone week, both for work related and occasional care. And it must have been Harold Holt-I now take his name in vain-and the crew of that Russian submarine which picked him up off the beach, who organised that child-care subsidy system which sees 274,000 Australian families receiving some government assistance with their fees. For the last eight months the government have accused us of everything under the sun, but they had better not have the gall to come in here, as they have done, and criticise us our child-care policies over the last 13 years-policies which they ripped off hand over fist for their election policy document, policies which have helped Australia develop one of the most advanced child-care systems in the world, and policies which they are now discarding. Under Labor we built Australia's child-care sector into the thriving industry it is today based on three key principlessupply, quality, and affordability-foundations that are now in the process of being eroded by this government. Operational subsidies were paid with the aim of increasing supply in those areas shunned by the private child-care sector. Commercial operators did not consider it economically viable to set their businesses up in areas where they could not make a profit on their operations. The only hope that rural and regional areas had of child care equivalent to those services offered in the cities was via subsidies. Operational subsidies offer quality and a high standard of service for children; children who, because of their age-with most of them being under two-need the extra attention and extra care which the private sector cannot and does not provide. Lastly, the operational subsidies provide affordability for parents who were not in a position to even consider private child care. The subsidies range from $21.40 a week for children under three to $14.35 a week for those aged three and over. The message is very clear: if you attack operational subsidies, you attack those three pillars underpinning child care in this country over the last 13 years. Without the subsidies, supply will dwindle and community centres will be ditched by low income parents seeking even cheaper options-backyard operations without accreditation, operations which are not governed by quality guidelines. And without this subsidy quality will suffer. As I said, money used by community centres goes to the hiring of extra and specialised staff trained in caring for those kids under two, and they are the majority of the kids who use these centres today. The money also goes towards food for the kids, for their nappies, equipment and activities. Without the for money, centres will now have to make choices. Which comers do they cut? Is it the staff? Is it the hot meal for the kids? Do they not provide nappies if mothers forget to send them with the children? Affordability will just go out the window. If the loss of the subsidy is passed on to the parents-many of the centres have said to me, and are now saying very publicly, that is what they intend to do-that is a pretty hefty smack in the hip pocket of the parents using those centres. If you are a low income family in my electorate, a struggling family living in Villawood with one child under three and receiving the maximum fee relief as it stands at this very moment, your fees will go up from $29.50, following the factoring in of the child-care cash rebate, to $50.90 a week. We are not talking about middle-class welfare here. We are not talking about mum and dad and the bub living comfortably and in relaxed fashion on the North Shore. I do not represent those people. We are talking about Struggle Street in Villawood, where $20 extra a week means the revision of those three or four evening meals. It is clothes on the kids' backs. It is the weekly public transport for the husband to go to work-and it is usually a one income family. But the Minister for Family Services says no. She slips on her real estate agent's hat and starts talking about margins and differentials, the economic jargon she has been given to recite for ours and the nation's benefitparrot fashion, I might add. It is all numbers and figures and budget realities. You would not think that she is talking about the realities of child care and the lives of kids. Her economic theory is just that-theory. The reality of the situation is that you cannot cut money from community based child care. If you do, it will have to be made up from somewhere. It is taken from the parents or cut from the quality of service offered, or it is a combination of both. If you do not believe me, why do people in the industry now have so much to say about it? The National President of the Australian Early Childhood Association, Ms Tonia Godhard, has gone on record as saying exactly that; that the price of care would have to go up by the amount of the withdrawn subsidy and that some centres might have to close. She said: The only other way to solve that is a major reduction in quality, and I think that is a sad thing. Basically, the community based model could be on the way out. The head of the Institute of Early Childhood at Macquarie University, June Wangmann, said that the loss of the subsidy would force some parents to take their children out of child care and put them into some backyard child-care minding operation. She stated: It is really going to price good quality child out of the reach of a lot of families. The Queensland Director of the Creche and Kindergarten Association, Susan Whitakersurely, this is penetrating down to some of those members from Queensland-said that fees in Queensland would rise by between $15 and $20 a week. She said: Either you put all of that on to the parents, which is unfair, or you try to shed things out of our budget. And that is almost impossible. The minister herself, for all her stiff upper lip in this House day in and day out, trying to sell the abolition of the operational subsidies to the press, admitted that she could not rule out the closure of community child-care centres. She said: I can't give a guarantee because it will depend on how those centres, how their management structure, operate. I say thank you to the member for Pearce. I do not think she will be shedding one tear when that happens. The minister talks about management structures. The community based centres are not geared for competition with the private sector. They are non-profit organisations, generally operated by a local government authority, a community organisation, or a religious or charitable organisation. Any profits that the community based centres make-and very little it is-go straight back into improving their operations. The management structure of the centres usually consists of parents and other members of the community. Those people are very much involved. They are not professional centre owner managers. They do not make a living from the business, but how are they to operate or organise the business of their centre in the cut throat competition against private operations, often twice their size, when they have their own jobs to attend to and their own families to bring up? The parents and community run these centres and do so for a very good reason. It is not for reasons of profit or for reasons of expanding the centre's business. It is so the centre itself is as responsive as possible to the needs of their children and their neighbours' care children. They run the centre so it benefits their children first and foremost. With the parents in charge and overseeing the centres, who is going to be hurt by any bad decision they make? Of course, it is their kids and, through their kids, themselves. The unfairness of the situation is compounded by the glee with which the minister's actions have been met by the private childcare sector. They are out there now saying, 'Terrific. This will lead to a more competitive industry,' because they know that they are the ones set up and ready to grab the opportunity. They are in a prime position to exploit this situation. Further still, as Sheryle Bagwell, a columnist with the Financial Review, quite rightly points out, if community based centres increase their fees once the operational subsidy goes-as the majority of them are now saying they will do-this will certainly lead to the private centres doing the same. Up goes the price. Once the operational subsidies have gone, we will have the community based centres dropping off like flies, while others will be operating in a diminished capacity. Private centres will step into the gap, presenting themselves as the higher quality service for parents and their children. Naturally, they will raise their fees to take advantage of the extra business. For the parents, who have little or no choice, where do they tum? This really suits the Minister for Family Services and the government right down to the ground. Caught up in her party's userpays ideology, the minister now would like private enterprise to run all child-care centres-but it just cannot work that way. I had hoped that my colleagues in the National Party-and I was listening to the member for Parkes-would have pointed this out to the minister. The majority of community based centres, as I said earlier, are in where the private sector have reckoned time and time again that they would not be able to make a buck out of it. For that, you can read rural areas, country areas. When we were in government, we just could not stand by and watch the opportunities for child care being given to some Australians and not to others, so we maintained the operational subsidies. Even with the subsidies as they now stand, parents in regional and rural Australia find child-care costs sometimes too much. The Australian Law Reform Commission, in its report to the government in 1994, took submissions on child care from families living in rural and remote areas. Parents running the centres said that costs for child care in their areas were higher because they had to offer financial incentives to carers from urban areas, they had increased costs for food and they had increased costs for building materials as a result of greater transport and communications costs. Remember that this is with the operational subsidies for community based child care already in place. What will be the case once those subsidies disappear? Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, I know that you are a member of the National Party, but how can National Party members stand by and watch this happen to their own communities in those rural areas? How can they stand by and see community based child care in their heartlands diminish? It has been a source of constant amazement for me since March to see how far the National Party is willing to sell its natural constituency short to remain tight with its coalition partners. I believe this is another step in the National Party's shameful abrogation of its duties to its constituents. The people in rural Australia need representatives who are going to stand up for their rights in the rural centre. They deserve the same access to child care as any parent in the city. But without these subsidies they are just not going to get it. The Minister for Family Services says everything is going to be okay. Her government is going to give the community based centres $8.3 billion-to make up, I might add, areas for the $115 million it will rip off those centres over the next three years. What unmitigated gall on behalf of the minister to even contemplate saying something like that. Would she have suffered that type of stupidity from clients back in her real estate days in Perth? Of course she would not have. Neither should the Australian parents whom she is now trying to snow with that sort of pathetic reasoning. I say this to the minister: Australian parents have now got your number. They have got you and your government marked. You gave them your word on child care and you have now double crossed them. Now you are taking the parents for fools. Those parents in my electorate of Prospect with young children in community based centres will not be forgetting in a hurry what you and your government have done to them. This is the first time that I have ed with so many petitions and cries for help from these community based organisationssome run by the Uniting Church, others by local government authorities. What we are really seeing is a cut in services that had not been budgeted for and planned for-but a commitment was given two days before the election by the then shadow minister. He made a public statement and distributed his press release and his letter for all to read. He said, 'We in government will never' - never, I emphasise-'cut the subsidies to community based child care centres.' It is now only eight months later. As I have said in this speech, this government is now used to saying one thing and delivering another. An old Indian story talked about the forked tongue. We have seen the forked tongue in child-care centres, and the government is going to wear the responsibility and the blame for it. The people will not forget, and your government will continue to be reminded of it. (Time expired) Debate (on motion by Mr Ruddock) adjourned.
